form.definition: noun P or p is the sixteenth letter of the English alphabet.

dictionary.entry: P\times,0\ symbol used to show that a driver has a provisional licence. See P-plate.

form.definition: abbreviation for the Latin words per annum, which mean 'in each year'. Your salary will be $40,000 p.a.
abbreviation for public-address system.
noun The pace of something is the speed at which it moves or happens. We'll have to work at a faster pace. I can't keep up with the pace of city life.
noun A pace is the distance that you move with each step when you walk. Take two paces to the left.
verb If you pace an area or pace it out, you estimate its size by counting how many steps you take to walk over it. I've paced out the room, and it's not big enough to fit the furniture in.

keep pace If you keep pace with someone or something, you keep up with them. You do something at the same speed as they do. My kids know so much about computersI can't keep pace with them. The union claimed that wage rises hadn't kept pace with inflation.

pace up and down If you pace up and down, you repeatedly walk a short distance and back again, because you are anxious or worried. I paced up and down in the corridor while I waited to hear if the operation had succeeded.

pace yourself If you pace yourself, you do not work or run as fast as you possibly could, because you want to be able to keep doing it for a long time without getting tired. I paced myself to finish the marathon in five hours.
noun A pacifist is someone who believes that it is wrong to use violence or fight wars to resolve conflicts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pacifism

form.definition: verb If you pacify someone, you make them less angry. Martin was furious, but I managed to pacify him by promising it would be his turn next.

verb If you pack a bag or case, you fill it with the things that you'll need while you're away from home. It's time to pack our bags and go home. Did you remember to pack your swimmers? The train leaves in an hour and I haven't even packed yet!

verb If you pack things, you put them into containers or packets. Jagdish got a job packing components in the warehouse. I packed up a lot of old books for the school fete. Be sure to pack your toys away tidily.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is unpack.

form.definition: verb If people or things pack or are packed into a space, there is not enough space for them to fit comfortably. Fifty of us packed into a small classroom.
noun A pack is a bag, usually one that you carry on your back. They travelled around Australia with no more than they could carry in their packs.
noun A pack of animals is a group of them that stay together. We were attacked by a pack of wolves.
noun A pack of cards is a set of 52 playing cards.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is deck.

form.definition: pack off In informal language, if you say you pack someone off somewhere, you mean that you send them there, usually because you want to get rid of them. We packed Aunt Jane off to my sister in Queensland.
pack of lies In informal language, if you say that something is a pack of lies, you mean that it is totally untrue. How dare you tell people Jack and I are getting a divorcethat's a pack of lies!
noun A package is a small parcel or bundle.
noun Packaging is the material such as cardboard and wrapping paper that something is packed or wrapped up in. You have to pay $3 extra for packaging and postage.
adjective If a room is packed, it is crowded with people or things. The train was packedI couldn't get a seat. The room was packed with enthusiastic students.
noun A packet is a small package or container, usually made of cardboard or plastic. I opened a new packet of breakfast cereal.
noun In informal language, a packet is a lot of money. He made a packet on the share market.
noun A pact between countries or people is an agreement to help each other. Austra-lia signed a defence pact with Indonesia.

dictionary.entry:
padpAdpadspaddedpadding 1a noun A pad is a flat piece of something soft, such as foam rubber or cotton wool. It is used for cleaning or protecting things. The nurse bathed the wound and covered it with a gauze pad. Fold the
verb If you pad something, you line the inside of it with a layer of something soft. He padded the chair seats with foam rubber.
noun A pad of writing paper is a large number of sheets held together on one edge, usually the top. You can tear off single sheets of paper from the pad.
noun An animal's pads are the soft parts on the bottom of its paws.
... WORD FAMILY noun padding The padding's coming out of my jacket.

form.definition: noun A paddle is an oar which you use to row a canoe or a small boat.
verb If you paddle a canoe, you use a paddle to move the boat through the water. We paddled a little further upstream.
verb If you paddle at the beach, you stay on the edge of the water and only your feet get wet. We just paddled, because it was too cold to go swimming.

noun A paddock is an area of land where animals are kept. Usually it is fenced to prevent the animals from wandering away. Most of our sheep are grazing in the far paddockthere's not enough food around the homestead.

noun A padlock is a metal lock with a curved bar which you pass through what you want to lock or join, and then click it shut. The catch on the gate has a heavy padlock through it. Do you have the key?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb padlock Did you remember to padlock the chest?

form.definition: noun A paediatrician is a doctor who specialises in treating children. ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is pediatrician. ... WORD FAMILY adjective paediatric (or pediatric) She's a paediatric surgeon.
noun A page is one of the sheets of paper that make up something such as a book, newspaper or magazine. Another word for this is leaf.

noun A page is one side of a sheet of paper in something such as a book, newspaper or magazine. Pages are usually numbered. Turn to page 18 and start reading from the second paragraph. 2a verb If someone pages you in a public area, such as an airport or department store, they call out your name over a loudspeaker because they need to contact you urgently. Could you please page my husband on the factory floor. Paging Mr Rajtelephone for you.
verb You can also page someone electronically by sending a message to a device that they carry with them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pager Most doctors carry a pager with them so they can be easily contacted.

form.definition: verb Paid is the past tense and past participle of pay.

adjective If you are a paid-up member of a club or union, you are a financial member. Efrem is a paid-up member of the Metalworkers Union. We'd better check which members are paid-up and send a reminder to the others.
noun A pain is a feeling somewhere in your body that hurts. Carla suffered a lot of pain from her sprained ankle. I felt a sudden pain in my chest.
noun If something causes you pain, it worries or upsets you. Neelam's bad behaviour caused her mother a lot of pain.
a pain in the neck In informal language, if you say someone is a pain in the neck, you mean that they are very irritating and annoying.

pains If you take pains to do something, you make a considerable effort over it. You try very hard to do it well. Everyone went to great pains to make the office party a success. Sanjay was at pains to explain why I hadn't gained promotion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective painful The bruise was very painful. It was painful to leave my family behind.adverb painfully

form.definition: adjective If someone is painstaking, they are very careful and thorough. Painstaking research has gone into the project. You must be more painstaking about your work.

noun Paint is a coloured or white substance made on an oil or water base. You put it on an object in order to protect it or to make it look attractive. Watch it! That red paint is dripping from your brush. CAUTION! WET PAINT!
verb If you paint something such as a house or a piece of furniture, you cover it with paint.
verb If you paint someone or something, you draw a picture of them on a surface using paint. Albert Namatjira painted many landscape scenes of inland Australia.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See painting. noun painter Tom's a painter and decorator. Sidney Long was a famous Australian painter.

form.definition: noun A painting is a picture that someone has made using paint. Did you see the exhibition of paintings by Arthur Boyd? ...an oil painting.

noun A pair of things is two things of the same type, size and shape which belong together, and are used for the same purpose. These two gloves aren't a pairone's a size seven and one's a size nine. ...a pair of socks.

noun You also use pair to describe certain things that are made up of two corresponding sides or parts. Is this your only pair of glasses? ...a pair of scissors. ...a pair of trousers. ...a pair of pyjamas.
noun If two people, things or animals are together, you can call them a pair. Tom and Jill are a very funny pair. Our zoo has bought a pair of tigers.
noun In informal language, a pal is a friend. Be a pal and help me move this table, will you?

noun A palace is a very large and magnificent house, usually originally built for members of a royal family to live in. ...Buckingham Palace. Have you seen Roberto's new house? It's a real palace on the waterfront.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective palatial The company's headquarters are palatial.

form.definition: noun Your palate is the top part of the inside of your mouth.
noun Your palate is also your capacity to enjoy or appreciate good food. Sylvain has a very fine palate for wine. This curry is too spicy for my palate.
adjective If something is pale, it is very light in colour. It is not strong or bright. She wore a pale pink dress with white accessories. A pale light filtered through the trees.
adjective If someone is pale, their skin hasn't got much colour. Are you sick? You look very pale. She turned pale with shock.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pale He paled at the thought of speaking in public.

form.definition: noun Your palm is the inside part of your hand, from your wrist to your fingers.

palm off In informal language, if you say someone palms something off on you, you mean that they give or sell you something of poor quality. They palmed off that awful old lounge suite on a young couple who were just setting up house.
verb If your heart palpitates, it beats faster than normal with an irregular beat.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun palpitation I consulted my doctor as I'd been experiencing palpitations.

form.definition: adjective If something is paltry, it is so small in amount that it is practically useless or worthless. Considering how rich Ken is, he gives a paltry amount of money to charity.

verb If you pamper someone, you look after them very well, sometimes so much that it's not good for them. Alberto absolutely pampers his daughterno toy is too expensive for her. You've been working hard all weekjust sit down and be pampered.
noun A pamphlet is a very thin book with a paper cover. The migrant resource centre should have pamphlets on health and women's issues.

dictionary.entry:
panpAnpanspannedpanning 1a noun A pan is a broad shallow container with a long handle. It is used to cook food on the stove. Put all the ingredients into a pan and heat them for five minutes, stirring all the time. ...a frying pan. b noun A pan is any sort of broad shallow
verb If you pan for gold, you rinse soil in a shallow dish to separate the gold from the sand and silt.
verb In informal language, if you say someone pans something, you mean that they criticise it severely. The critics panned the movie but it was a box office success.

form.definition: noun A pancake is a thin, flat, round piece of fried batter that often has a sweet or savoury filling folded up in it. You usually eat it hot.
noun The pancreas is a gland near the stomach which produces a hormone called insulin. It also produces a liquid which is important for digestion.
noun Pandemonium is noisy confusion or a wild tumult. The crowd was quiet until the election results were announcedthen pandemonium broke out.

verb If someone panders to you, they do everything you want, usually because they want something in return. Some of Kelly's so-called friends pander to her because she has so much money. He's a spoilt brathis parents pander to his every whim.
noun A pane of glass is one sheet of glass in a window or door.

noun A panel is a group of people chosen to make decisions on a particular issue or to discuss something at a meeting. The interview panel voted five to two in favour of the first applicant. A panel of five experts will discuss government plans to reduce the migrant intake.
noun A panel is a separate square or rectangular piece that forms part of a larger whole. The door has two glass panels at the top. The painting was done on three panels.
noun A control panel or instrument panel is a board with switches and knobs on it that is used to operate a machine or piece of equipment.
noun A panel van is a vehicle used by people such as painters and plumbers. Instead of a back seat and a boot like a normal car, it has space for tools and equipment.
noun A pang is a sudden, sharp feeling of discomfort such as pain, hunger, regret or sadness.

noun Panic is a sudden feeling of fear or anxiety. It makes you unable to think or act calmly and sensibly. The fire caused panic and confusionpeople rushed to the exit doors, screaming with fright. The news of the war caused panic at the stock exchange.
verb If you panic, you lose control of yourself because you're frightened or anxious. Police urged the crowd not to panic, and to stay in their seats.
noun A panorama is a view over a very wide area.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective panoramic

form.definition: verb If you pant after exercise or exertion, you breathe hard and quickly. Every time I run up the stairs to the office, I arrive puffing and panting.
noun A pant is a quick short breath.[qr

dictionary.entry:
pantihose`pAnti:h@Uz
noun Pantihose are women's tights.
... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is pantyhose.

form.definition: noun A pantomime is a silent play. The actors use body movements to tell the story.
noun A pantry is a large cupboard in a kitchen or a small room near a kitchen where you keep stores of food.
Pants are also women's undergarments. Other words for this are briefs and knickers.

catch someone with their pants down In informal language, if you say you catch someone with their pants down, you mean you surprise them in a very embarrassing situation. The papers caught the alderman with his pants downhe was photographed accepting a bribe from a building developer.
noun Paper is a flexible material in thin, flat sheets. It is made from wood fibres. You write or print on paper, and you can use it for wrapping things up.
noun A paper is a newspaper. I haven't read today's paper yet.

noun A paper is a written examination. Navaz failed her chemistry paper but she passed in maths. 4a noun Paper is also wallpaper. I don't like the paper in the lounge room. Do you think we should paint the walls instead?
verb If you paper a room, you put wallpaper on the walls.
paper over If you paper something over, you try to hide it. Don't paper over the truthwe all know that the company's in real difficulties.
papers Your papers are important documents, such as your passport, birth certificate and driver's licence. The policeman at the border asked Oleg for his papers.
noun A paperback is a book with a flexible cardboard cover. Paperbacks are much cheaper than hardbacks.

noun When a woman has a Pap smear, she has a medical test which involves taking cells from the cervix of her womb. It is a routine test to discover any abnormalities which may eventually develop into cancer.
form.note: ... NOTEThis is a shortened form of Papanicolaou smear.

form.definition: noun Par for a golf course, or a section of it, is the number of strokes an average golfer would hit on that particular course or section. Gregor got around in three under par.
on a par If someone or something is on a par with someone or something else, they are equal or equivalent to them. His swearing is on a par with her rudeness.

noun You wear a parachute on your back to enable you to float to the ground when you jump from an aircraft. When you pull the ripcord, the parachute opens and floats like a balloon, carrying you to the ground.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb parachute They parachuted down over the fields of wheat.noun parachutist The crowd watched the parachutists floating down in a circle.

form.definition: noun A parade is a procession of people. Often they are celebrating something. On Australia Day, a parade of schoolchildren marched down the main street to the Town Hall.
noun A parade is also an inspection ceremony for groups of people such as soldiers or police officers. The Prime Minister attended the military parade.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb parade The soldiers were parading past the Prime Minister.

form.definition: noun In the Christian religion, paradise is heaven.
noun A paradise is also a very beautiful and pleasant place or situation. This holiday is paradisenothing to worry about, just peace and relaxation.
noun A paradox is a statement or situation which seems to contradict itself, and yet it is true. It is a paradox that the more roads are built, the more they become clogged with traffic.
noun You can describe someone or something as a paradox when they seem to contain contradictory elements. Vladimir is a real paradoxhe talks about healthy living but he still eats junk food.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective paradoxical adverb paradoxically

form.definition: noun A paragraph is a short section in a piece of writing which contains a few sentences dealing with the same ideas. To show that you are starting a new paragraph, you begin writing on a new line.
adjective If two lines are parallel, they are the same distance from each other at every point along the way. They run along beside each other and never become any closer together or further apart.

noun A parallel is a situation that is similar or equivalent in some way to something else that happens. There is a parallel between Jana's problems and the difficulties I faced when I first arrived in Australia.

verb If one situation parallels another one, there is something similar or equivalent about them. Li-Ling's experience parallels yoursyou were both transferred to an outback town, liked it, and settled there.

verb If something paralyses you, it affects you so that you can't move your body. The injury that Rajir received in the car crash paralysed him for life. I was paralysed with fear when I saw the mugger had a knife.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun paralysis

form.definition: noun A paramedic is someone such as an ambulance officer who has basic medical or first-aid training and is employed to help the medical profession. The paramedics applied mouth-to-mouth resuscitation to the accident victims.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective paramedical

form.definition: adjective If something is of paramount importance, it is extremely important. It is more important than anything else.
noun Paranoia is a mental illness in which someone believes that other people are plotting against them and trying to harm them.
noun In informal language, if you say someone has paranoia, you mean that they don't trust other people. You don't mean that they really have the illness of paranoia.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective paranoid Zoltan's paranoid about not being invited to things.adjective paranoid I'm paranoid about snakes.

form.definition: noun When a large number of different things are all collected together, they can be referred to as paraphernalia. You wouldn't believe the paraphernalia Lucia has accumulated over the years. I loaded all the paraphernalia for my presentation into the back of the car.

verb If you paraphrase what someone says, you say the same thing using different words. Can you paraphrase those instructions on how to operate the video? The instruction manual is very difficult to follow.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun paraphrase

form.definition: noun A paraplegic is someone who has lost the use of their body from the waist down. They can't move their legs at all.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun paraplegia Paraplegia can be the result of brain damage.

form.definition: noun A parasite is an animal or plant that lives on another larger animal or plant and feeds off it.

noun In informal language, you can call someone a parasite if they expect someone else to pay for their food, accommodation or other things. Vinotha's been staying with us for two months now, and has never even offered to buy the grocerieswhat a parasite!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective parasitic

form.definition: noun A parcel is a box or package wrapped up in paper or cardboard, often so as to be sent to someone in the mail. I had to go to the post office to collect a parcel.
verb In formal language, if you say you pardon someone, you mean that you forgive them. I can never pardon my parents for the way they treated me.
interjection In informal language, people sometimes say pardon if they don't hear what someone says and they want them to repeat it. Pardon, Maria? I can't hear a word. Could you speak up, please?

I beg your pardon In fairly formal language, people sometimes say I beg your pardon to apologise to someone for doing something that may have upset them. I beg your pardon. I didn't see you earlier. How are you?
noun Your parents are your mother and your father. Both his parents came to the concert. This form must be signed by a parent or guardian.
noun A parish is a district with its own church and minister or priest.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun parishioner Father Jones is meeting some parishioners for lunch today.

form.definition: noun A park is an area of land with grass and trees. It is usually in a town or city and is open to the public. People often go to parks for picnics or to relax and enjoy themselves.
verb If you park a vehicle, you leave it standing somewhere. Why don't you park the car in the driveway?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun parking Parking is not allowed on this side of the street.

form.definition: noun A parka is a warm jacket with a hood to fit over the head. It is often waterproof.

dictionary.entry: parliament`pa:l@m@nt noun Parliament is made up of those people who are elected to govern a country or state and to decide on its laws. In the Australian parliament, there is an upper and a lower house. ...a Member of Parliament. ...State Parliament. ...Federal Parliament in Canberra. ... WORD FAMILY noun parliamentarian adjective parliamentary ...a parliamentary sitting.

form.definition: noun A parody is a funny imitation of something serious, such as a TV program, advertisement or someone's behaviour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb parody (parodies, parodied, parodying) The other kids used to parody my accent.

form.definition: noun If a prisoner is released on parole, they are set free before they have served all of their sentence, on condition that they behave well. The judge imposed a sentence of ten years' jail, with the possibility of parole after seven years.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb parole

form.definition: noun Parquet is a type of flooring. It is made of small pieces of wood cut into rectangular shapes which are then glued together to form a pattern.
noun A parrot is a medium-sized bird with a curved beak. There are many different kinds of parrot. Some have brightly coloured feathers and can be taught to copy things that people say.
verb If you parrot something, you simply repeat what someone else has said, without thinking about it yourself. There's more to history than being able to parrot names and dates.
verb If you parry something such as an attack or a criticism, you defend yourself against it. The Prime Minister parried the journalist's question on the economy by quoting statistics.
noun Parsley is a small plant with curly leaves. You use it as a herb in cooking or for garnishing a dish.

noun A part of something is one of the pieces or elements that make up the whole. Where does this part of the jigsaw go? The film is being shown in two parts, with an interval between. It can be hard to get spare parts for foreign cars. b noun A part of something is also some of it considered separately from the rest. I particularly enjoyed the last part of the film. Do you know this part of Sydney? Could you explain the part about totals again?

noun Part of something is some of it, but not the whole of it. I could only manage to eat part of the pie. I lay awake for a large part of the night. Part of the problem is that he just doesn't try hard enough.

noun If something is part of something, it is one of the things that make it up. It took her a while to settle in and become part of the team. Learning to make your own decisions is part of growing up.
noun A part in a play or movie is a particular character or role. She only had a small part, but she was very good.
noun Your part in an activity is the role you play in it, or how you are involved in it. POLICE INVESTIGATE BANK MANAGER'S PART IN DARING ROBBERY
noun A part in your hair is a line which you make with a comb. You then brush or comb your hair in opposite directions from this line.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is parting.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say you part from someone, you mean that you go away from them. We parted at the station, where we caught separate trains. After ten years of marriage, we have decided to part.
part of speech In grammar, a part of speech is a particular class of word, such as noun, verb, adjective, adverb, preposition, conjunction and interjection.
part with If you part with something, you reluctantly give it away or give it to someone else. I just can't part with this ragged old teddy bearI've had it for forty years.

take part If you take part in a particular activity, you get involved in it along with other people. Another, more formal word for this is participate. Irene took part in the discussion on teenage drinking at the youth club last night.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb partly noun parting

form.definition: adjective If something is partial, it is not complete or whole. Alfonso has partial memory loss as a result of his accident. I'm afraid there's only partial reimbursement of your dental coststhe health fund doesn't pay in full.

adjective If someone is partial in making a decision or judgment, they are biased. They unfairly favour one person more than another. She claimed that the council was partial in its approval of planning applications.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is impartial.

form.definition: partial to In rather formal language, if you say you are partial to something, you mean that you particularly like it. I'm very partial to chocolate cake.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb partially

form.definition: noun If you participate in an activity, you take part in it. You join other people in doing it. We'd like everyone to participate in the discussionplease give us your ideas.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun participant noun participation

form.definition: noun In grammar, a participle is a particular form of a verb. In English, the present participle is formed with -ing and the past participle is often formed with -ed. They are used in compound tenses and sometimes as adjectives.
noun A particle is a very small piece of something. The Consumer Association advises that particles of glass have been found in some bottles of tomato sauce.
adjective A particular thing is a specific thing. It refers to one thing only. They'd sold out of the particular brand I wanted. Is there anything particular you'd like to do?
adjective Particular also means special or more than usual. Please take particular care of my daughtershe's never been away from home before.

adjective If someone is particular about something, they are very careful about it because it's important to them. They want it to be exactly right. Rhonda is very particular about her clotheseverything has to match perfectly.
noun A particular is a detail or piece of information. The solicitor rang up to check on a certain particular. Please provide particulars of any tenancy held by you or your spouse.
in particular In particular means 'especially'. I enjoyed the bookthe last part in particular.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb particularly ...a particularly interesting bushwalk.

form.definition: noun A partition is a thin wall which screens off one part of a room from another. The rooms in this ward each have four beds, with partitions around them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb partition Why don't you partition this side of the room off?

form.definition: noun Your partner is your husband, wife or other person you have a relationship with. Do come to our house-warming party, and please bring your partner.
noun Your partner is the person you are doing something with or sharing something with. Is Jan your tennis partner? ...my business partner.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb partner Who's partnering Emma tonight?noun partnership Yanica's part-owner of a florist shop she's in partnership with Omar.

form.definition: adverb If you work or study part-time, you work or study for only part of the whole working week. Carla's working part-time nowas a check-out operator on Thursday nights and Saturdays.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is full-time. ... WORD FAMILY adjective part-time He's a part-time student at university.noun part-timer

form.definition: noun A party is a social gathering where people meet, often to celebrate a special occasion. Generally drinks and light food are served. Are you invited to Paul's 2lst birthday party? ...engagement party.
noun A party is an organisation or group of people who all believe in the same political ideas. Marcel belongs to the Australian Labor Party. I've lost faith in all the major parties.
noun A party can also be a group of people who are all doing the same thing together. Reg joined a party of senior citizens who were going on a coach trip to the Blue Mountains.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb party (parties, partied, partying) Paul and Jenny partied nearly all night.

form.definition: verb If you pass somewhere, you move through or along, following a route that you are supposed to take. Our train passed through Port Augusta. Pass right along, please. We passed over the bridge and turned left. The road passes under the railway bridge.
verb If you pass something, you go past it. Rick got there before ushe must have passed us on the road.
verb If you pass something such as an exam or test, you are successful in it. Anjali has finally passed the Australian Medical Association examshe can work as a doctor now.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is fail.

form.definition: verb If you pass something to someone, you give it to them, often by hand. Pass me the salt, please. Vasanthi passed a note on to the girl sitting next to her. I want to pass a message to Mr Tedeschi. Rodolfo deftly passed the ball to his teammate.
verb If you pass something, you excrete it. Molly went to see the doctor because she'd been passing blood in her urine. They decided to wait and see if the child would pass the coin naturally.

verb If time passes, it goes by. If you pass the time, you spend it doing something. The year has passed so quicklyI can't believe it's my birthday again. How can we pass the time until the plane leaves?
noun A pass is a narrow way or road through mountains.
noun In games such as football, soccer and hockey, a pass is throwing, kicking or hitting the ball to another player in your team.

noun A pass is a special document which shows that you are allowed to do something, such as go to the movies cheaply or travel on public transport free or at a reduced rate. My kids are always losing their bus passes. You need a pass to get into the building on the weekend.
make a pass In informal language, if you say someone makes a pass at you, you mean they show that they are sexually interested in you. Frank made a pass at Lucy but she didn't fancy him.
pass away In formal language, if you say someone passes away, you mean that they die. Grandpa passed away peacefully last night.
If you pass out, you faint or become unconscious. Luis said he felt dizzy and then suddenly passed out. She was almost passing out with the pain.
noun A passage is a narrow space that you walk through. It can be in a building or between two walls, high fences or hedges.
2 noun A passage is also a part of a written text or music. Read the following passage and answer the questions on the sheet provided.
noun A passenger is someone who travels in a vehicle, boat or plane, but who is not the driver.
noun Passion is a strong feeling of emotion, very often love, for someone.
noun A passion is also a very great interest in something or enthusiasm for it. Lucia has a passion for gardening at the moment.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective passionate He is passionate about his motorbike.

form.definition: noun A passionfruit is a fruit with a hard dark outside. You can eat the inside, which is soft yellow flesh with black seeds.

adjective If you say a sentence or a verb is passive, you mean that the doer of the action is not the subject of the sentence or the verb. The sentence 'I was bitten by the dog' is passive because the dog is doing the biting but is not the subject.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is active.

form.definition: adjective If someone is passive, they let things happen around them, without doing anything themselves. Don't be so passiveyou have to make more of an effort.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb passively

form.definition: noun Your passport is an official document issued by the country of which you are a citizen. It contains your photograph and other personal information and must be shown when you travel from one country to another. You must show some ID, such as a driver's licence or passport. Ilona holds an Australian passport.
noun A password is a secret word or combination of characters which you must know to be allowed into a particular place or to use something such as a computer. <Enter your password>.
noun The past is the time before now, and all the things that happened then. Mother just can't forget the past. In the past, people used horses as a means of transport.
noun Your past is everything that has happened to you up to now. Mehmet's not too proud of his past, I've heard.
adjective Past refers to something that happened before now. Past experience shows us that it won't work. Past presidents of the society are granted honorary life membership.

preposition If you go past something, you move by it. You pass it. We drove past some beautiful beaches. I'd walked past the postbox before I remembered to post the letter. Could you get some milk if you're going past the shops?
adverb If you go past, you move by something or someone. Henry didn't look up as I walked past.
preposition When you are telling the time, you use past to say how many minutes later it is than a full hour. It's six minutes past eight already. I'll meet you at half past two.
past continuous In English grammar, the past continuous is another expression for the imperfect tense.

simple past In English grammar, the simple past is the tense you use to say that something happened before now, without saying anything about when it happened in relation to other events. 'I went', 'she sang' and 'he worked' are examples of the simple past.
noun Pasta is a type of food made from flour mixed with eggs and water. Usually you cook it by boiling it in water. Spaghetti, macaroni, noodles and lasagne are all types of pasta.
noun Paste is glue, especially a water-soluble glue that you use for sticking things such as paper and cardboard.
noun A paste is a very thick liquid. Mix the flour and butter into a paste and then add the eggs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb paste Paste the edges down neatly.

form.definition: adjective A pastel colour is a soft, pale colour. I bought a pastel pink blouse. I don't like these pastel shadesI want something bright and bold. ... WORD FAMILY noun pastel The baby's room was decorated in pastels.
verb When milk is pasteurised, it is heated to a certain temperature in order to kill any bacteria in it.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is pasteurize.

form.definition: noun A pastime is something that you enjoy doing in your leisure time. My favourite pastime is gardeningI find it so relaxing.
noun Pastry is made from flour, butter and milk or water. It is then rolled out in flat sheets and used as the base or crust for tarts and pies. ...shortcrust pastry. ...filo pastry. ...puff pastry.
noun A pastry is a small cake or tart, usually fairly plain. Waitresses came round with trays of pastries. For breakfast we offer a selection of pastries and preserves.
noun Pasture is fertile grassy land that is used to graze cattle and sheep.

dictionary.entry:
pasty`pEIsti: <for sense 1>; for sense 2>, /\times,0\psti, pasti/pasties
adjective If someone looks pasty, they look pale and sick. After studying hard for so many weeks, we all looked pretty pasty.
noun A pasty is a vegetable and meat pie.

form.definition: verb If you pat something, you tap it gently several times. Don't hit the dog, Ingajust pat it gently, like this. I patted the paper dry with a cloth.
adjective If someone gives a pat answer or makes a pat remark, they speak very readily, but perhaps not sincerely. Miriam always has a pat excuse for anything that happens.
off pat If you learn or know something off pat, you learn or know it perfectly, so that you have no difficulty in remembering it. By the end of the evening I had all their names and faces off pat.
pat on the back If you give someone a pat on the back, you congratulate them for something. You really deserve a pat on the back for organising the party single-handed!
noun A patch is a piece of material that you use to mend or cover something. You'd best put a patch over the tear in these pants. ...an eye patch.

noun A patch is a small area contained in something larger. There are damp patches on the walls. I'm starting a vegetable patch at the bottom of the garden. The painting makes a nice patch of colour on that wall. I sat down in a patch of shade.
noun A patch can also be a period of time in someone's life. I'm going through a bad patch at the moment. She's had fewer patches of unemployment than most actors.

not a patch In informal language, if you say that one person or thing is not a patch on another, you mean that they are not nearly as good. Colin's not a patch on Nick at tennis. The canteen food's not bad, but it's not a patch on my mum's home cooking.
patch up In informal language, if you say you patch up a quarrel or a disagreement with someone, you make friends with them again. Let's patch up our differences and work together.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb patch Can you patch this hole in my jeans?adjective patchy (patchier, patchiest) The dye is a bit patchy. Her results were patchysome good and some bad.

form.definition: noun A patent is an official document saying that you are the only person who is allowed to make or sell something that you've invented. If you licence other people to make or sell it, they have to pay you royalties. Statistics show that more than one hundred patents were taken out by Australian inventors last year.

adjective In formal language, if you say that something is patent, you mean that it is obvious. Ali is a patent liarno-one could possibly believe his stories. It is patent that they haven't got the funds to support their operations.
patent leather Patent leather is a type of leather with a shiny surface, sometimes used to make shoes or handbags.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb patent There are several stages involved in patenting an invention.adverb patently The suggestion is patently ridiculous.

form.definition: adjective Paternal means relating to a father. Let me give you some paternal advice, young man! My paternal grandfather came from Poland.
form.note: ... NOTE the female equivalent of this is maternal.

form.definition: noun Paternity is a formal word for being a father. Blood tests were arranged to determine the paternity of the child.
noun A path is a track. We trudged up the path to the top of the hill.
noun A path is a strip of ground, often cemented, which is intended for people to walk on. The path led up to the front door.
adjective If something is pathetic, it makes you feel pity. It was pathetic to see Carina struggle to get out of bedshe used to be so lively before her illness.

adjective If someone or something is pathetic, they are completely useless or fail miserably at something they are trying to do. You're patheticgo away! It was a pathetic attempt to hide the facts from us.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb pathetically He was pathetically weak.

form.definition: noun Pathology is a branch of medicine. It has to do with the way diseases start and the effect they have on the body.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pathologist

form.definition: noun A patient is someone who is being treated by a doctor or other medical professional.
adjective If you are patient, you are willing to wait calmly for something to happen. Be patient, it's nearly ready.

adjective If you are patient with someone, you are kind and tolerant even when they are slow or make mistakes. You do not get cross with them when they do something wrong. Amalia is our best trainershe is so amazingly patient with our young apprentices.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun patience She shows enormous patience.adverb patiently

form.definition: noun A patio is an outdoor living area, usually next to a house. The party spilled out onto the patio.
noun A patriarch is a man who is the head of a family or tribe.
noun A patriot is someone who loves their country and is loyal to it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective patriotic noun patriotism

form.definition: verb If someone patrols an area or place, they go around it to keep watch on it and make sure that everything is as it should be. These premises are regularly patrolled by security guards.
noun A patrol is a group of people such as police officers, soldiers or guards who patrol an area. Police have stepped up patrols in order to curb drink-driving.
on patrol When police or guards are on patrol, they are on duty, patrolling certain areas.

noun A patron is someone who supports people and organisations involved in the arts, charities, or campaigns for causes. They give money or let their name be used. The Lord Mayor agreed to be our patron. Become a patron of the zoo and receive regular news of events.
noun Patron is a formal word for a customer of a shop, restaurant or pub. PATRONS ARE ASKED TO WEAR SHOESNO THONGS ALLOWED
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See patronise. noun patronage The patronage of the Minister has been very valuable over the years.

form.definition: verb If someone patronises you, they treat you kindly but in a way that makes it clear that they think they're better than you. Stop patronising meI know how to drive a car.
verb In formal language, if you say you patronise a shop or service, you mean that you are a customer there. I shall not patronise your establishment again after the way I've been treated.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is patronize. ... WORD FAMILY adjective patronising

form.definition: verb If something patters on a surface, it makes a soft tapping sound. What a relief to hear the rain pattering down on the roof! Can you hear feet pattering upstairs? Sally must be out of bed again.
verb When someone patters, they talk very fast or eagerly. Often they have worked out in advance what they are going to say. The salesperson kept pattering about what a good buy it was.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun patter I lay awake listening to the patter of rain. Don't believe Jack's patter.

form.definition: noun A pattern is a design which is repeated several times. I bought a tablecloth with a floral pattern. Be sure and match up the pattern at the joins. She was doodling geometric patterns on her jotter.
noun A pattern is also a model or guide for making something. ...a dress pattern. You'll find cut-out patterns for all our fabulous Christmas ideas inside this magazine.

noun A pattern is the particular or usual way that something happens or is done. There seems to be a consistent pattern to the behaviour of these teenagers. I fell into a pattern of coming home from work and turning on the television. ... WORD FAMILY adjective patterned With a patterned blouse you'll need to wear a plain skirt.

noun A pause is a period when you stop doing something. Often, you have a short rest before you continue. Let's take a pause nowis five minutes OK? There was a pause and then the banging started again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pause Rita paused for a few seconds, then continued her speech.

form.definition: verb If you pave an area, you lay something such as bricks, tiles or cement on the ground to make it firm and dry to walk on.
noun The pavement is the concrete footpath beside a road for pedestrians to walk on. You mustn't step off the pavement once the red light begins to flash.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is footpath.

form.definition: noun A pavilion is a small building in a park or sports ground, or a temporary building at an exhibition.
noun A pavlova is a type of sweet made from lots of egg whites. It is a very large meringue and is often decorated with fruit and cream.
noun A paw is an animal's foot. The cat stood up on its hind paws to reach the table.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb paw The dog pawed at the front door to show us it wanted to get out.

form.definition: verb If you pawn something valuable that you own, you leave it at a special shop as can sell the item if you don't pay back the money, plus interest, within a certain time.
noun In chess, a pawn is one of the eight least powerful pieces.
noun If you are a pawn, someone is using you to get what they want without really considering what is best for you. The workers are just pawns in the struggle between unions and management.

verb If you pay money to someone, you give them money in exchange for something they are selling or have done for you. How much did you pay for that table? It's a real struggle to pay the bills. Can I pay by credit card? Freda never pays her share.
verb If your employer pays you your wages, they give you the money you have earned by working. Salaries are paid into employees' accounts every fortnight.
noun Your pay is your wages or salary. Your pay went into your account this morning.

verb If it pays you to do something, you get an advantage by doing it. It'll pay you to make a special effort with this exercise, as it's part of the assessment. It always pays to dress smartly for an interview.

verb If someone pays for something they do, they suffer as a result of it. I played tennis for three hours and I certainly paid for it the next dayevery muscle ached. Phil paid a high price for the divorcehe had a nervous breakdown as a result.

pay a visit If you pay someone a visit, you visit them. Do pay us a visit if you're ever in Brisbane. We paid a visit to the art gallery in the afternoon. Can you wait a moment? I need to pay a visit to the toilet.

pay back (a) If you pay someone back, you give them back money that you have borrowed from them. Could you lend me $20? I'll pay you back on Friday. We're paying back the mortgage over twenty-five years.
(b) If you pay someone back for something they have done, you take revenge on them. You do something bad to them to make up for what they've done to you. I'll pay you back for this, you bastard!

pay off (a) If you pay off a loan, you repay it in instalments over a certain period. I'm still paying off the debts I ran up while I was out of work. We'd paid off the house and the kids had left home, so we decided to start our own business. (b) If something that you do pays off, you are successful as a result of it, even though there was a risk that you might not. Taking that course to update my skills certainly paid off.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun payment You can make four monthly payments of $50. We're still waiting for payment.

form.definition: abbreviation for pay as you earn. This means that your employer deducts tax from your wages and pays it directly to the government.
noun If you are on the payroll of a company, you are employed by them and receive regular wages or a salary.

abbreviation for Parents and Citizens Association. A P & C is an organisation for the parents of children at a particular school,and other local people. They raise money to buy things for the school and support it in other ways.

dictionary.entry: Pde \times,0\ abbreviation for Parade. It is used when you write an address. ...17 Anzac Pde.

form.definition: noun Peas are the small round green seeds of a common climbing plant. They are cooked and eaten as a vegetable, or in soup.
like two peas in a pod If you say that two people are like two peas in a pod, you mean that they look very much alike. Bill and his brother are like two peas in a pod, don't you think?
noun If there is peace, there is no fighting or war. After some months of uneasy peace, the violence began again.
noun Peace is a state of calmness or quietness. I really enjoy the peace of country life during the holidays. I just want to be left in peace to do my own work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb peaceful We seek a peaceful solution to the conflict. It's so peaceful here.

form.definition: noun A peach is a round, soft, juicy fruit with slightly furry, yellowish-red skin. It has a rather large, rough stone.
noun A peak is the highest part, usually pointed, of a mountain. After two hours of climbing we reached the peak. We looked out of the plane and saw the snowy peaks below us.

noun The peak of something is the highest level or value that it reaches. The crowd's excitement reached a peak when Jim scored. The temperature can reach 41 degrees at its peak. This job was the peak of her career.
verb When something peaks, it reaches its highest level or value. The flood will peak at 2 p.m.
adjective Peak times are when something happens the most or there is most demand for a service. We got caught up in traffic during the peak hour rush. This offer is not available during peak periods.
verb If a large bell such as a church bell peals, it makes a long, loud ringing sound.
noun A pearl is like a round white shiny bead. Pearls grow in oysters and are used in expensive jewellery such as necklaces, bracelets and earrings. ...a string of pearls.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pearl ...a pearl necklace.

form.definition: noun A peasant is someone who lives and works on a farm, usually in a poor country, and has little education.

noun If you call someone a peasant, you mean that they have bad manners or are not cultured or sophisticated. Phil's a real peasanthe's such a messy eater it's embarrassing to go to a restaurant with him.

noun Peat is black or dark brown soil which consists of decaying plant material such as leaves, grasses and roots. It is found in marshy areas. Dried blocks of peat can be used to improve soil or as a fuel, instead of coal.
noun A pebble is a small smooth round stone which is found on the seashore or a river bed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pebbly ...a pebbly beach.

form.definition: verb If a bird pecks, it uses its beak to strike out at something or to eat something. There's that cockatoo again, pecking at our plums.
verb If you peck at something, you eat just a bit of it, usually because you're not very hungry. That's unusual for Bharati to be pecking at her dinner. Is she sick?
noun A peck is a light kiss. Daria gave her mother a peck on the cheek.
adjective In informal language, if you say you are peckish, you mean you are rather hungry. Have you got anything to eat? I'm a bit peckish.

adjective If something is peculiar, it is odd, strange, or different in some way. What's wrong with Sam? He gave me a peculiar look a minute ago. That's peculiarI'm sure I left my glasses here. There's a peculiar smell in the room.
adjective In informal language, if you say you feel peculiar, you mean you feel sick.

peculiar to In formal language, if you say that something is peculiar to a certain person or place, you mean that it is associated only with them. No-one or nowhere else has it or does it. This sort of wine is peculiar to the Hunter region in New South Wales.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun peculiarity (peculiarities) You'll soon get used to her personal peculiarities.adverb peculiarly Juan behaved rather peculiarly.

form.definition: noun A pedal is a lever which you press with your foot in order to make something work. Push down the clutch pedal before you put the car into gear. ...piano pedal. ...bike pedal.
verb If you pedal a bike, you push the two pedals round with your feet so that the bike moves. I had to pedal very hard to get up the hill.

adjective If someone is pedantic, they are very concerned that things should be absolutely correct, and they make a big fuss about unimportant details. Rosa really irritates me, the way she's so pedantic about grammar. You owe me $10, or $9.87 to be pedantic.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pedant

form.definition: verb If someone peddles things, they try to sell them in an informal way, often because they are illegal or stolen. Jake buys up old paintings and peddles them at markets on weekends. There was someone in the pub last night peddling cheap videos.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pedlar My grandfather was a pedlar in Poland. ...a drug pedlar.

form.definition: noun A pedestal is a base on which something such as a statue or sculpture stands.
put on a pedestal If you put someone on a pedestal, you admire them so much that you are not realistic about their faults.
noun In a town or city, a pedestrian is a person who is walking rather than travelling in a vehicle. There were many pedestrians waiting to cross the road. The cyclist collided with a pedestrian.

adjective In formal language, if you say that something is pedestrian, you mean that it is ordinary and rather boring. His presentation was rather pedestrianit could have done with more sparkle. The food is well cooked, but distinctly pedestrian.
pedestrian crossing A pedestrian crossing is a specially marked place where pedestrians can cross the street and cars must stop for them.
verb In informal language, if you say someone pees, you mean that they urinate. I feel a sharp pain when I pee.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pee I was desperate for a pee.

form.definition: verb If you peek at something, you have a quick look at it, often because you are not supposed to be looking at it at all. Lana managed to peek at her neighbour's new boyfriend as he came up the drive. I peeked at the files she'd left on her desk. Close your eyes and count to tenand no peeking! ... WORD FAMILY noun peek Tanya offered us a peek at her wedding dress. I took a peek at the letter.

noun The peel of a fruit is its skin. Cut up the peel of an orange and add it to the cake mixture. She removed the apple peel in a single strip. The man in the cartoon is about to slip on a banana peel.

verb If you peel something, you remove its skin or outer layer. I was peeling the potatoes when the doorbell rang. He peeled the children out of their wet clothes and put them under a hot shower. I peeled the price tag off the box of chocolates.

verb If something peels, the top layer of it comes away from the surface in flakes. The paint on the doors is peeling badly. Peeling skin is a sign of serious damage by the sun. After a couple of weeks the scab peeled off.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun peeling Throw the peelings out in the rubbish bin.

form.definition: verb If you peep at something, you look at it quickly. I peeped through the window and the children were all playing quietly.
noun A peep is a quick look. I've had a peep at the figures, but I haven't gone over them properly.

noun In informal language, if you say that you don't hear a peep out of someone, you mean that they don't make any noise or say anything. The baby's very quietI haven't heard a peep out of him all night. Get on with your work, and if I hear another peep out of you in the next half hour there'll be trouble.

verb If you peer at someone or something, you look at them very closely and carefully, often because you can't see very well. Sudha peered through the windscreen trying to see the road through the rain.
noun Your peers are the people who are the same age or at the same stage in life as you are. Marcelo gets on well with his peers but is not too popular with his superiors.
verb In informal language, if you say that something peeves you, you mean that you're annoyed or irritated about it. It really peeves me that she gets away with behaving so badly.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective peeved He seemed peeved at something I'd said.

form.definition: If someone is peevish, they are irritable, usually in a petty and unreasonable way. The children were overtired and being peevish. Samira's always got some peevish complaint about her colleagues.
noun A peg is a small wooden or plastic clip which you use to hang clothes out on a line to dry. Why don't you hand me the pegs and I'll put the washing on the line?
noun A peg on a wall or door is a projecting piece of wood or metal on which you can hang clothes. Let me hang your coat on the peg behind the door.
verb If you peg something somewhere, you fasten it there with a peg. Don't peg the clothes on the line nowit's going to rain.
verb If you peg something such as a price, you fix it at a certain level, so that it cannot go any higher or lower.
peg out In informal language, if you say that someone pegs out, you mean they die. He pegged out when he was eighty-nine. The pain was so unbearable I thought I was going to peg out on the spot.

square peg in a round hole If you say that someone is a square peg in a round hole, you mean that they don't fit in well with their situation. Giving an outdoor type like her a desk job was trying to fit a square peg in a round hole.

take down a peg or two If you say someone should be taken down a peg or two, you mean that they're too arrogant and sure of themselves, and it would be good if they failed at something and were humiliated.
verb If you pelt someone, you throw things at them hard and fast. The demonstrators pelted the police with apples and rotten eggs.

verb In informal language, if you say you pelt somewhere, you mean that you go there very fast. Eric pelted to the shops to try to reach them before closing time. The bus pelted down the hill and screeched to a halt.
noun An animal's pelt is its fur. Koalas used to be killed for their pelts.
pelt down In informal language, if you say the rain is pelting down, you mean that it's coming down very hard and fast.
noun Your pelvis is the group of bones at the base of your spine, at the level of your hips.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pelvic

form.definition: noun A pen is an instrument with ink in it which you use for writing. ...a fountain pen. ...a ballpoint pen. ...a felt-tip pen. Has anyone seen my pen? I sketched it first in pencil and then went over it in pen. I marked the errors with a red pen.
noun A pen is an enclosure for farm animals.
adjective Penal means relating to the punishment of criminals. New South Wales was established as a penal colony for British criminals. There are many faults in the current penal system.

verb If someone is penalised for doing something wrong, they are punished for it. Linda was penalised for cheating in the examshe's been barred from all future exams. Tax evasion is heavily penalised. If you drop the ball, you're penalised ten points.
verb If you are penalised for something, you are unfairly put at a disadvantage because of it. They complained that they were being penalised for their honesty.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING of this is penalize.

form.definition: noun A penalty is a fine or punishment for breaking the law or doing something wrong. There are harsh penalties for deliberately giving false or misleading information. NO SMOKING: MAXIMUM PENALTY $200 There's a two-point penalty for each incorrect answer.
noun A penalty is a disadvantage that you have because of something that you choose to do. One of the penalties of living here is that it's a long drive into town.
noun In sport, a penalty is a free kick or shot at the goal from in front of the goal. It is awarded by the referee because the opposing team has committed a foul.

noun A pencil is a thin piece of wood with a black or coloured substance running through the middle. You use it to write or draw. I bought my niece a box of coloured pencils for Christmas. I wrote in pencil in case I needed to rub anything out. ...an eyebrow pencil. ...a pencil sharpener. ...a pencil case.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pencil (pencils, pencilled, pencilling) She pencilled her initials at the bottom of each page.

form.definition: noun A pendant is a piece of jewellery which you can attach to a chain and wear as a necklace. She was wearing a heart-shaped pendant.
verb In rather formal language, if something penetrates something, it pierces it or breaks through it. The bullet penetrated the door and buried itself in the opposite wall.
verb If you penetrate a place, you manage to get into it although it is very difficult. It is not clear how the burglars managed to penetrate the high-security area.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective penetrating She looked at me with a penetrating stare. He has a penetrating mind.noun penetration

form.definition: noun A penfriend is someone you write to regularly and come to know well although you haven't met them, usually because they are in another country or in prison.
noun A penguin is a bird which cannot fly and lives in the cold southern parts of the world, including some parts of Australia.
noun Penicillin is an antibiotic medicine which doctors may prescribe if their patients have a disease caused by bacteria.
noun A peninsula is a piece of land that is almost surrounded by the sea. It is linked to the mainland by just a thin strip of land.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective peninsular

form.definition: noun A penis is the outer sexual organ of a male person or animal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective penile

form.definition: noun A penknife is a small knife which you can carry in your pocket. It has a small blade which folds back into the handle, and often other attachments such as a corkscrew.
noun A penny is a copper or bronze coin of low value which was once used as currency in Australia, and is still used in Great Britain and some other countries.
a pretty penny If you say something cost you a pretty penny, you mean that it was very expensive.

in for a penny, in for a pound If you say in for a penny, in for a pound, you mean that if you have decided or started to do something, then you may as well make a good job of it and complete it properly. It took a lot longer than I expected, but in for a penny, in for a pound.
not have a penny to your name If you say someone doesn't have a penny to their name, you mean that they are very poor.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective penniless Yosef's pennilesshis company has filed for bankruptcy.

form.definition: noun A pension is a regular payment, usually made by the Department of Social Security, to certain categories of people. A pension is usually higher than a benefit. ...age pension. ...sole parent pension. ...disability pension.
noun A pension is also a regular payment that you receive after you retire, if you have contributed to a superannuation scheme. Another word for this is annuity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pensioner

form.definition: noun A pentathlon is an athletic competition which consists of five different events. The person with the highest total score wins.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pentathlete

form.definition: noun A penthouse is a luxury flat or apartment built on the top of a building, with very good views.

noun People means men, women and childrenhuman beings in general. The restaurant was full of people. I don't know why people put up with being treated like that. Each copy of the magazine is read by an average of five people.
noun People also refers to the members of a particular group. The people in our street all got together for a party on Australia Day. Do you people want to come along too?

noun People refers to all the human beings of a particular country or race. The people of Australia will vote in a federal election next month. The peoples of south-east Asia have an amazing variety of languages and cultures.
noun Pepper is a hot tasting spice which is used to flavour food. Pass the pepper and salt, please. ...black pepper. ...white pepper.
noun A pepper is a vegetable which can be green, red or yellow. Another word for this is capsicum. I had a rice salad with mixed peppers. ...stuffed peppers.
noun Peppermint is a plant which produces a strongly flavoured oil that is used in things such as toothpaste and confectionery.

preposition Per means 'in each' or 'for each'. You often use it to describe payments that are made regularly at certain intervals. The rent is $300 per week. Allow half a bottle of wine per person. They charge $10 per adult and $6 per child.

verb In formal language, if you say you perceive something, you mean that you notice it by means of your senses or understanding. Dogs are able to perceive notes of much higher pitch than humans can. I perceived that I had offended her in some way.

verb If people perceive something in a particular way, they have that impression of it or opinion about it. He is generally perceived to be a fine orator. Her contemporaries perceived nothing wrong in this behaviour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See perception.

form.definition: adverb Per cent means 'in each hundred'. One per cent of something is one hundredth of it, ten per cent is one tenth of it, and so on. In written language, this is usually represented by the symbol %. I'm paying eight per cent interest on the loan. Over sixty per cent of people were in favour of the idea. Flora got ninety per cent in the test.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING of this is percent. ... WORD FAMILY noun percentage What percentage of your students come from overseas?

form.definition: noun Your perception of something is the impression or opinion that you form about it as a result of observation. It was my perception that he was irritated about something.
noun Perception is the ability to notice things and to understand them. She was a woman of unusual perception, with many ideas in advance of her time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See perceive. adjective perceptive That was very perceptive of youI didn't expect anyone to notice.

form.definition: verb If a bird perches on something such as the branch of a tree, it stands on it for a while. The pigeons like to perch on that window ledge. Can you see that kookaburra perched in the gum tree?
noun A perch is a short rod made especially for a bird to rest on. The parrot flew back to its perch.

verb If you perch somewhere, you sit there, usually for only a short time. She was perched on the edge of the chair, ready to get up at any moment. Don't worry about me, I'll perch on the edge of this table.
verb When you make coffee in a percolator, the coffee percolates as the boiling water passes over the coffee grounds and through the filter. Would you like some coffee? It's just percolating.
verb If news percolates through a group of people, it spreads gradually from one person to another.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun percolator I'm buying Anna a percolator for her housewarmingshe hates instant coffee.

dictionary.entry:
perfect`p@:fEkt <for the adjective and noun>; <for the
adjective If something is perfect, it is faultless or correct in every detail. Very few people get a perfect score. Her English is almost perfect.
adjective If something is in perfect condition, it is undamaged or complete. When I lent you my dress, it was in perfect conditionnow it's got stains all over it.
adjective If something is perfect, you think it is so good that it couldn't possibly be better. The weather has been perfect all week. That dress would be perfect for the wedding.
adjective Perfect is also used to mean 'absolute' or 'complete' when you want to emphasise the noun following it. I felt like a perfect fool! It was so embarrassing. He behaved like a perfect gentleman. The whole thing was a perfect disaster.
verb If you perfect something, you improve it until you have got it exactly right. He perfected his command of Japanese in the ten years he spent there. I'm still working to perfect this recipe.
noun In grammar, the perfect is a compound tense formed by the auxiliary verb 'have' and the past participle of the main verb. 'I have seen' is an example of the perfect or present perfect; 'I had seen' is an example of the past perfect.
... WORD FAMILY noun perfectionist He's such a perfectionisthe won't stop until it's just right!adverb perfectly She completed the task perfectly. It's perfectly obvious he's lying.

form.definition: verb If you perform, you appear in public in something such as a play, concert or opera. She's performing with the Sydney Symphony Orchestra next month. We decided to perform Shakespeare's 'Romeo and Juliet'. Rob's taught his dog to perform tricks.

verb In formal language, if you perform a task, you do it. Anita has always performed her duties diligently. What function does this part of the machine perform? You can't expect me to perform miracles.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun performance There are two performances on Saturday.noun performer He's an experienced theatrical performer.

form.definition: noun Perfume is a liquid with a very pleasant smell. You put it on your skin or on your clothes so that you smell nice.
noun A perfume is a pleasant smell. These flowers have a lovely perfume.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb perfume The jasmine blossoms perfumed the air.

form.definition: noun A pergola is a wooden structure in a garden on which you can grow climbing plants.

adverb You use perhaps to show that you are not certain about something. Perhaps you're right but I have to be absolutely certain before I make any decisions about it. Perhaps Ray will be there tonight. She is perhaps the best worker we've got.
adverb You can also use perhaps to make a request, offer or statement sound more gentle or polite. Could you perhaps move over a little? Perhaps you'd like to visit the art gallery?
noun Peril is a formal word meaning 'danger' or 'risk'. They have braved great perils in search of adventure.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective perilous

form.definition: noun A period is a length of time. There was a short period of rain after lunch, but it's been mostly fine. All payments must be completed within a period of six months. After a period of calm, fighting began again.
noun A period in someone's life is a particular stage of it. My years in New Guinea were an exciting period.
noun A period is also a particular time in history. These houses were all built in the Federation period, around the turn of the century.
noun In a school, a period is a length of time during which a particular subject is taught. We've got French in the first period after lunch.
noun A period is a full stop.
noun When a woman has a period, she is menstruating.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective period We all wore period costume for the colonial bush dance.adjective periodic There will be periodic showers over the next few days.adverb periodically I'll look in periodically to see how you're getting on.

form.definition: noun A periodical is a magazine or journal which is published regularly, for example monthly or quarterly.

adjective If something is peripheral, it is not of central importance to the matter in question. Let's not waste time on these peripheral details. These activities are peripheral to their core business.
noun A computer peripheral is an optional extra to the system, such as a printer or a modem.
verb In formal language, if you say someone perishes, you mean that they die, often in an accident or a battle. They erected a memorial to those who perished on the vessel.
adjective Perishable goods are things that rot or decay quickly if they are not kept in special conditions. Lifeline urgently needs food donationsbut only tins, no perishable items.
verb If you perjure yourself, you tell a lie while you are under oath in a court of law. This is a serious offence.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun perjury (perjuries) Malik committed perjury to try to help his friend.

form.definition: noun A perk is an extra benefit you receive from your job, in addition to your wages or salary. The salary is average, but the perks are goodI get to travel a bit and we get a discount on everything the company makes.
adjective If something is permanent, it lasts for ever or for a long time. He was left with a permanent limp after the accident.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is temporary.

form.definition: If you have a permanent job, your employer has made a commitment to employ you until you resign or are dismissed. The benefits include regular working hours, holiday pay, sick pay and superannuation.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is casual. ... WORD FAMILY adverb permanently

form.definition: noun If you have permission to do something, you are officially allowed to do it. Do ask your parents' permission before you call our 005 number.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See permit.

dictionary.entry:
permitp@`mIt <for the verb>; <for the noun>, /\times,0\pmt/permitspermittedpermitting
verb In formal language, if you say you permit someone to do something, you mean that you allow them to do it. Smoking is permitted in this area only. We were permitted to leave early to beat the train strike.
noun A permit is an official document which entitles you to do something. Do I need a permit to fish here? You must display your parking permit on your windscreen.
verb If something permits something to happen, it makes it possible. This treatment permits 60% of patients to lead a normal life.

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say that someone perpetrates a crime or an error, you mean that they commit it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun perpetrator The perpetrators of the outrage were never identified.

form.definition: adjective If something is perpetual, it never stops or changes. They live in perpetual fear for their lives.
adjective If something is perpetual, it happens repeatedly. I'm fed up with her perpetual whinging.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb perpetually

form.definition: verb If someone persecutes you, they harm you or treat you unjustly, often because of your religious or political beliefs. The regime was accused of persecuting ethnic minorities.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun persecution

form.definition: verb If you persevere with something, you keep doing it even though you feel like giving up because it is so hard. Minh persevered and finally managed to pass his exams. You must persevere with your training if you want to see results.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun perseverance She showed great perseverance in the face of hardships and setbacks.

form.definition: noun Persian is the language of Iran. It is also called Farsi.
verb If you persist with something, you don't stop even though you don't achieve what you want immediately. He persisted with his questioning until she revealed what the problem was.

verb If something persists, it continues even though you've tried to stop it. If you persist in annoying me I shall make a formal complaint. If the pain persists for more than a few days, you should consult a doctor.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun persistence At last his persistence was rewarded.adjective persistent I've been troubled by a persistent cough.adverb persistently

form.definition: noun A person is a man, woman or childa human being. I heard a person coming up the stairs. The maximum capacity of the lift is 18 persons. Allow 200 g of pasta per person.

noun In grammar, verbs sometimes have special forms to show which person is doing the action. The first person is the one speaking or writing ('I' or 'we'); the second person is the one being addressed ('you'); the third person is anyone or anything else.

in person If you do something in person, you do it yourself. You do not get someone else to do it for you. Applicants must attend in person to be interviewed. I actually met the Prime Minister in person.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See people. adjective See personal.

form.definition: adjective If something is personal, it relates to just one person and not to a whole group. All letters published represent the personal opinion of the correspondents and not the editorial policy of the magazine. I ran a personal best time for the 10 km last weekend.

adjective If something is personal, it is private. Could I have a word with you about a personal matter? I don't want everyone knowing my personal business. The letter was marked 'personal and confidential'.
adjective If someone makes a personal remark, they say something about someone that is rude or likely to offend them. Let's change the subjectthis argument's getting too personal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb personally Don't take his criticism so personally. Personally, I agree with Sam.

form.definition: noun Your personality is your character. It is the way you react to other people and get onwith them. Sara has a very pleasant personalityshe's always cheerful and willing to help.
noun If you say that someone has personality, you mean that they are lively and good fun. We need someone with plenty of personality for this job. Rafael's nice enough, but he lacks personality.
noun A personality is someone who is mentioned in the media a lot. We need to get a personality to open the exhibition. She was voted TV Personality of the Year.
verb If you say someone personifies a quality or a statement, you mean that they are a very good example of it. Ten-Hu personifies what I was just saying about spoilt children.
noun The personnel in a company or business are the employees collectively. There have been several changes of personnel in the last three months.

noun In some large organisations, Personnel is the department which deals with hiring, training and dismissing employees. You have to fill in the tax form and take it back to Personnel. This is Sandra, who works in Personnel.
form.note: ... ANOTHER EXPRESSION for this is human resources.

form.definition: verb Perspire is a more polite word for sweat. After a few minutes of running, I began to perspire.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun perspiration Drops of perspiration ran down my back.

form.definition: verb If you persuade someone to do something, you talk to them and get them to agree to do it, although at first they don't want to. I wanted to leave, but Simon persuaded me to stay. I've never been able to persuade my kids to eat vegetables.
