verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone or something persuades you that something is true, you mean that they make you believe it. The jury was persuaded by the prosecutor's forceful argument. Her distress persuaded me that she was genuinely sorry.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun persuasion She resisted all my attempts at persuasion.adjective persuasive He made me a very persuasive offer.

form.definition: adjective If someone is pert, they are very pleased with themselves and are a bit rude or cheeky.

adjective In formal language, if you say that something is pertinent, you mean that it is relevant. It has to do with the matter being discussed. I don't think your question is pertinentwe're talking about salaries, not holi-days. Kimberley's just made a very pertinent point.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pertinence

form.definition: verb If something perturbs you, it worries or disturbs you. I was perturbed that he seemed so unhappy. The increase in violent crime is most perturbing. He refused to let the initially poor results perturb him.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun perturbance She showed not the slightest perturbance at the news.

form.definition: adjective If someone is perverse, they are deliberately awkward. You are so perversewhy do you want to go out wearing clothes like those?

dictionary.entry:
pervert`p@:v@:t <for the noun>; <for the verb>, /\times,0\pvt/
noun A pervert is someone who takes part in socially unacceptable sexual practices.
verb If you pervert someone, you teach them low moral standards. You encourage immoral behaviour.
verb If you pervert something, you change it for the worse, or interfere with it so as to alter the final outcome. If you lie under oath, you can be charged with perverting the course of justice.
... WORD FAMILY adjective perverted I don't know how anyone can enjoy such perverted activities.noun perversion

form.definition: noun Pessimism is a feeling that things will go wrong or turn out badly. The report concluded on a note of pessimism.
noun Pessimism is also a general tendency to look on the dark side of things. I made an effort to overcome my natural pessimism.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is optimism. ... WORD FAMILY noun pessimist Don't be such a pessimistyou're doing really well.adjective pessimistic I grew more and more pessimistic about the project.

form.definition: noun A pest is a small animal or insect, such as a cockroach or rat, which damages food or crops. Rid your house of pestscall us now for safe and effective action!

noun In informal language, if you call someone or something a pest, you mean that they're a nuisance. Shirley's a real pestshe's always calling late at night for a chat. What a pest! I've lost my car keys.

verb If someone pesters you, they annoy you by disturbing you when you are busy or keeping on asking you to do something. Don't pester me now, kidsI'm trying to fix the drain. Anne's been pestering me for days to cut her hair.
noun A pet is an animal such as a cat or dog that you keep and look after in your home. Daniel has an unusual petit's a rat called Frank. Pets aren't allowed in these units.

noun In informal language, you can call someone a pet if they're particularly liked and looked after by someone in authority. Brian's the teacher's pethe never gets into trouble, no matter what he does. There's no point in working hardthe boss only ever promotes her pets.

verb If you pet an animal or a child, you stroke it or pat it lightly to show your affection for it. He sat petting the dog on his lap throughout the interview. The kids hate it when my mother tries to pet them.
noun A petal is one of the coloured parts that make up a flower.
verb If something peters out, it gradually comes to an end. His voice petered out as he realised that no-one was listening. We followed the track but it soon petered out in the bush.
adjective If you describe a woman or girl as petite, you mean that she is small and delicate. Daria has a very petite figure.

noun A petition is a document signed by many people, asking a government or other official body to do or prevent something. The students organised a petition for her reinstatement. Would you like to sign this petition against nuclear testing?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb petition We all petitioned the council to enforce the regulations.

form.definition: verb If something petrifies you, it frightens you very much. Anne was absolutely petrifiedshe'd always hated spiders, and there was a huge one right next to her on the wall. The mere thought of going to the dentist petrifies me.
noun Petrol is a liquid made from petroleum. It is the fuel used in most cars. The price of petrol is set to rise again.
noun Petroleum is a type of oil which is found under the ground or the sea bed. Petrol, paraffin, plastics and other products are made from it.
noun A petticoat is an article of underwear which women sometimes wear under dresses or skirts. It is like a light skirt. Sometimes it also has a sleeveless top part.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is slip.

form.definition: adjective If something is petty, it is small and relatively unimportant. I'm not interested in all the petty details. There has been an increase in petty crime.

adjective If someone is petty, they are mean and spend too much time worrying about small and unimportant things. We don't want a petty bureaucrat, we need someone with vision. Don't be so pettyElsa's apologised and that should be the end of it.
petty cash Petty cash is a small amount of money kept in an office to pay for minor expenses. If you have to take a taxi on company business you can claim it back from petty cash.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pettiness

form.definition: adjective If someone is petulant, they are cross and sulky about something that is not very important. He's always so petulant when he doesn't get his own way.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun petulance

form.definition: noun Pewter is a metal which is a dull silvery colour. It is a mixture of tin and lead. It is used for making things such as figurines and beer mugs.
noun A phantom is a ghost. They say the orchard is haunted by the phantom of a young man who hanged himself there.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective phantom Many people swear they've seen the phantom horse and rider.

form.definition: noun A pharmacist is someone who is qualified to prepare and dispense medicines for sick people. If you need a cold remedy, consult your pharmacist. ... WORD FAMILY noun pharmacy (pharmacies) The pharmacy is at the back of the chemist's shop.
noun A phase is a stage of development in a process. Young Josie is going through a silly phase. Phase 1 of the new building is costed at $4.5 million.
phase in If you phase something in, you introduce it gradually. The changes will be phased in over a period of two years.
phase out If you phase something out, you get rid of it gradually. The old style of bus pass is being phased out; all renewals will be of the new type.
adjective If something is phenomenal, it is outstanding or remarkable. His new record has had phenomenal success in the charts.

noun A phenomenon is something that happens or exists. It's an interesting phenomenonand scientists are puzzled about what causes it. Australia contains some spectacular natural phenomena, such as Uluru and the Great Barrier Reef.
exclamation Phew is a soft whistling sound which you make to indicate that you are relieved about something. Phew, thank goodness that's over!
noun If you study philosophy, you study difficult questions about things such as the meaning of life and the purpose of our existence.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun philosopher adjective philosophical

form.definition: noun Phlegm is the thick mucous which collects in your throat or chest when you have a bad cough or cold.
adjective If someone is phlegmatic, they are very calm, even when facing pressure. They do not get upset about things. She was phlegmatic about her disappointment.
noun If you have a phobia about something, you have an irrational fear of it. Ahmet has a phobia about spiders. I've got a phobia about speaking in public.

noun Phone is an informal shortened form of telephone. Be quiet, I'm on the phone. Could I use your phone, please? It's a local call. ... WORD FAMILY verb phone I'll phone you tomorrow.adjective phone We're in the phone book. ...a phone call. ...a phone card.
noun If you study phonetics, you study the sounds that are used in language.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective phonetic The phonetic spellings in this book use the International Phonetic Alphabet.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say that something is phoney, you mean that it is not genuine. It is fake or imitation. The police are on the lookout for teenagers using phoney driver's licences. It really irritates me when he puts on that phoney American accent.
adjective In informal language, if you say that someone is phoney, you mean that they are insincere. She pretends to be concerned and helpful, but she's totally phoney.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is phony.

form.definition: noun Photo is an informal shortened form of photograph. Let's take a photo of the class. The burglars stole our wedding photos.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective photo ...a photo album. You need to have some form of photo ID.

form.definition: noun A photocopy is a photographic copy of a document. You must submit the original certificate; a photocopy is not acceptable.
verb If you photocopy a document, you make a photographic copy of it. Could you photocopy this for me, please.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun photocopier The photocopier's broken down again we'll have to call the technician.

form.definition: adjective If someone is photogenic, they look good in photographs. Navaz is really photogenic, but I always come out looking terrible.

noun A photograph is a picture of someone or something that you take using a camera with a film in it. The negatives from the film are then printed as pictures. That's a very good photograph of Marycould I have a copy? ... WORD FAMILY verb photograph He was photographed leaving her house.noun photographer Have you booked the photographer for the wedding?adjective photographic I kept a photographic journal of my travels.noun photography/\times,0\ftgrfi/ I'm going to a class in nature photography.
noun A phrase is a group of words which go together. Don't worry about writing full sentencesjust use phrases to remind yourself. What does the phrase 'at the last gasp' mean?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb phrase The letter needs to be phrased a little more politely.

form.definition: adjective If something is physical, it can be seen and touched. The problems of pollution affect all aspects of our physical surroundings. It was good to correspond, but I really missed his physical presence.

adjective If something is physical, it relates to the human body. Juan has great physical strength. She was at the limit of physical endurance. The physical pain was terrible, but the mental torture was worse.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb physically Jarmila is physically very fit. You have to physically destroy the files.

form.definition: noun A physician is a doctor of medicine who diagnoses and treats disease in much the same way as a general practitioner, but who has extra years of training and has specialised in some area.
noun If you study physics, you study natural phenomena such as heat, light, electricity and gravity, and the laws that govern them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun physicist

form.definition: noun If you study physiology, you study the processes that happen inside living animals and plants, such as respiration and digestion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun physiologist

form.definition: noun A physiotherapist is a trained medical worker who helps patients to improve their physical movement or mobility, especially after sickness or injury.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun physiotherapy

form.definition: noun Your physique is your build. It is the shape of your body. Mario's been weightlifting for yearshe has a fine physique.
noun A piano is a musical instrument which has a set of black and white keys on a keyboard. Each key plays a different note when it is pressed down.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pianist

form.definition: verb If you pick flowers or fruit, you take them off the tree or plant they're growing on. Please don't pick the flowers in the Botanical Gardens. I got a seasonal job picking grapes.
verb If you pick something or someone, you choose it or decide to use it. We picked this hotel because of your terrific special offer. I've been picked for the netball team.
If you pick a fight or quarrel with someone, you deliberately try to start a fight or a quarrel. Sam's very aggressivehe's always picking a fight with someone.
noun A pick is a garden tool which you use to break up hard soil or rock. It consists of a curved metal bar with sharp ends which is attached at its centre to a wooden handle.
pick at If you pick at your food, you eat very little of it, usually because you are not hungry. Is Rajiv sick? He only picked at his lunch.
pick on If you pick on someone, you find fault with them unfairly. Why are you always picking on me? The others are just as bad.

pick up (a) If you pick something up, you lift or raise it, usually with your hands. The opposite of this is put down. I picked up the book and looked at the title. Please pick your clothes up off the floor. The crane picked up the statue and carried it over the fence.

(b) If you pick something up, you buy or acquire it without making a particular effort. Could you pick up a loaf at the shops? She's picked up some interesting objects on her travels. I picked up a nasty bug last week. I picked up a bit of Spanish from my cousin.
(c) If you pick someone up, you call for them, usually in a car, and then you go somewhere together. I'll pick you up at 7.30 and we should be there by 8.
(d) If you pick someone up, you meet them and become sexually or romantically involved with them straight away. Carlos picked up a new girl at the pub last Friday.

take your pick If you can take your pick of several things, you are able to choose whichever you want. Phil did so well in his exams that he could take his pick of the top universities. Take your pick from the range of tasty salads in our buffet.
the pick If you say that something or someone is the pick of a group, you mean that they are the best or most impressive. They're all talented kids, but Nino's the pick of them.

noun A picket is a group of trade unionists who are on strike and who stand outside their workplace to try to persuade other workers to join the strike. There was a peaceful picket outside the factorylots of banners and noise, but no violence.
picket fence A picket fence is made of wooden slats, with gaps between them.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb picket The workers picketed the entrance to the factory.

form.definition: noun A pickle is a vegetable such as an onion or cucumber which is preserved in a mixture of vinegar and water.
noun In informal language, a pickle is an awkward situation. I've got myself in a real pickle with this spreadsheet program. He found himself in a pickle when both women turned up at the same time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pickle ...pickled cabbage.

form.definition: noun A pickpocket is a thief who steals things from people's pockets or handbags. BEWARE OF PICKPOCKETSKEEP YOUR HAND ON YOUR BAG!
noun A picnic is an informal meal which you take with you to eat outdoors. Let's go to the park for a picnic.
no picnic In informal language, if you say that something is no picnic, you mean that it is quite difficult and there are many problems to solve. It's no picnic being a parent of teenage children.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb picnic (picnics, picknicked, picknicking

form.definition: noun A pictorial is a magazine or article that relies on pictures rather than text to tell the story.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pictorial ...a pictorial history of the colonial years.

form.definition: noun A picture is a drawing or photograph of something or someone. The walls were covered with pictures the children had drawn. Look at the picture on page 52. He showed me a picture of his wife. A picture is worth a thousand words.

noun A picture of something or someone is also an image of it that you have in your mind. I don't have a clear picture of what you mean. She was very different from the picture I'd formed from Jake's stories.
verb If you picture something in your mind, you imagine what it would be like. I can just picture her face when she finds out. I found it hard to picture Tam as a doctor.
noun If you say that someone or something looks a picture, you mean that they are very attractive. The garden looks a picture at the moment, with all the spring flowers.
noun A picture is also a movie. I saw a good picture last night.
the pictures In informal language, the pictures means a movie cinema. There's a good French film on at the pictures. Let's go to the pictures.

noun A pidgin is a language made up from pieces of two or more languages and used as a form of communication between people who have no language in common. When we went into the highlands of Papua New Guinea, we were able to communicate with many villagers who could speak pidgin.[qr

dictionary.entry:
piepa:I
noun A pie is a pastry case containing food such as meat, vegetables or fruit. You bake it in an oven. The kids' favourite meal is meat pie with tomato sauce and chips.

form.definition: noun A piece of something is a bit or part of it. He broke off a piece of chocolate and ate it. One of the pieces of the jigsaw is missing.
noun You can use piece to refer to one particular example of something referred to by an uncountable noun. I try to eat at least one piece of fruit every day. That's a very nice piece of furniture.

noun A piece is also something that someone has made up or created, such as a story or musical composition. This is a very interesting piece of writing. She played a number of modern pieces I hadn't heard before. This sculpture is one of his finest pieces.

piece together If you piece things together, you put them together in the proper way to create a whole. We pieced together the story from what the police and the neighbours told us. Archaeologists have managed to piece the fragments together and reconstruct the ship.
noun A pier is a long structure built out into the sea so that people can walk along it to get to and from boats that are tied up there. People often fish off piers.
noun A pier is a stout pillar that holds up a bridge. The bridge was condemned as unsafe after a boat collided with one of its piers.
verb If something sharp pierces an object, it makes a hole in it and goes into or through it. He died from a broken rib which pierced his lung. I had my ears pierced when I was fifteen.
noun A pig is a farm animal which gives us pork and bacon.
noun In informal language, if you call someone a pig, you mean that they're an unpleasant person. Tony's a pigyou should see how badly he treats Effie and the kids.

make a pig of yourself If you make a pig of yourself, you eat too much in a greedy way. Tom made a pig of himself at the party and threw up on the way home. I don't normally eat dessert, but just for once I'll make a pig of myself.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun piggery (piggeries) Mike has a piggeryhe's got about two hundred pigs.

form.definition: adjective If someone is pig-headed, they are stubborn. They always want to do things their way and refuse to listen to other people. Don't be so pig-headedcan't you admit it's not working and try something else?

noun A pigment is a substance that gives colour to something. Our quality recycled paper is coloured with vegetable dyes and other natural pigments. Albino animals lack pigment in their skin and eyes.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pigmentation These are natural variations in pigmentation.

form.definition: noun A pigsty is a pen or shelter for pigs on a farm.
noun If you call a room or house a pigsty, you mean that it is very dirty or messy. Come on kids, clear up this roomit's a real pigsty! I don't know how you can live in a pigsty like this.
noun A pile of things is several of them put on top of each other in one place. There's a pile of washing on the bed. I accidentally knocked over a pile of books that was standing on the floor.
noun A pile of something is a large amount of it. I've got a pile of work to do. She inherited a pile of money from her aunt.
noun The pile of a carpet or fabric is its soft raised surface.
noun Piles is an informal word for haemorrhoids.

verb If you pile things, you put them one on top of the other, either in a heap or in a neat stack. Just pile the clothes on the bedI'll sort them later. Jan managed to pile eight blocks before the tower collapsed.

verb If people pile into or out of somewhere, a group of them move in or out in a fairly haphazard way. We all piled into the car and went to the beach. The show was over and people were piling out of the theatre.

pile up (a) If things pile up, a lot of them accumulate because they are not being dealt with. A lot of correspondence piled up while I was away. Her problems piled up until she felt she could no longer cope.
(b) If cars pile up in a smash, several of them become involved as later ones drive into the wreckage.
noun A pile-up is a smash involving several vehicles. SEVEN DIE IN HORROR PILE-UP ON FREEWAY
verb If someone pilfers something, they steal, especially small amounts and inexpensive things. Joan pilfered her mother's milk money from the tin.
noun A pilgrim is someone who visits a holy place for religious reasons.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pilgrimage

form.definition: noun Pilipino is another word for Tagalog, the national language of the Philippines.
noun A pill is a tablet or capsule containing a drug that you take for medical reasons.
noun In informal language, if you call someone a pill, you mean that they're unpleasant or boring. I can't stand Bridgetshe's such a pill!
the pill The pill is a contraceptive drug that women can take to prevent them from becoming pregnant. I've been on the pill for three years.
noun A pillar is a tall column which supports something such as a roof or a statue.
noun A pillow is a soft oblong cushion that you have under your head when you sleep in bed.
noun A pillowcase is the cotton or polyester cover that a pillow is in when it's on the bed.
noun A pilot is someone who flies a plane. She's training for her pilot's licence.
noun A pilot is also someone with local knowledge who takes over from the captain of a ship to steer it out of a port or through dangerous waters.
adjective A pilot scheme is a new way of doing things that you try out on a small scale to see if it succeeds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pilot Greg pilots charter planes. We're piloting the scheme next month.

form.definition: noun A pimple is a red spot filled with pus that people, especially teenagers, can get on their face or body. Tania's very self-conscious about her pimples.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pimply (pimplier, pimpliest)[qr

dictionary.entry:
pinpInpinspinnedpinning
noun A pin is a thin piece of metal with a point at one end and a flat head at the other. You use pins to join pieces of fabric before you sew them, for example when you are making a garment or taking up a hem.
noun A pin can also be various other types of fastener that are used to hold something in place. For example, it can be short for drawing pin or safety pin. The little girl had a pin in her hair with a red bow attached to it.
verb If you pin something, you fasten or secure it with a pin. She pinned up the hem of her skirt. I pinned the nametag on my jacket. I spotted a notice pinned to the board.
pin down In informal language, if you say you pin someone down, you mean that you make them say definitely what they mean or what they intend to do. You don't let them continue to be vague. When I pinned him down, he couldn't produce any evidence in support of his claim.

form.definition: abbreviation for personal identification number. This is a sequence of figures which you have to key in when you use an automatic teller machine, to prove that you are authorised to use the card. No-one else is supposed to know your PIN.
form.note: ... NOTE You can also say PIN number or Pin number.

form.definition: verb If someone pinches you, they take part of your skin between their thumb and first finger and squeeze it. Stop it, Peterit's mean to pinch your little sister. She pinched his cheek playfully.
noun A pinch of something is a small amount of it. Add a pinch of salt and freshly ground black pepper.

verb In informal language, if you say someone pinches something, you mean that they steal it. I don't know where he got itI suspect he pinched it from work. She claimed that her former partner had pinched her best designs.

at a pinch If you say that you will do something at a pinch, you mean that you will do it, but only if it's absolutely necessary. I suppose I could go at a pinch, but it's not very convenient. The cottage can take six people comfortably, or eight at a pinch.

feel the pinch If you say that someone is feeling the pinch, you mean that things are very difficult for them financially. They do not have enough money to live comfortably. We've really been feeling the pinch since Mirek lost his job.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pinch He gave me a pinch when I started to doze off.

form.definition: verb If you pine for someone who is away, you miss them a lot and wish that they would come back. There's no point sitting around piningyou have to get on and make a life for yourself.
pine away If someone pines away, they are very sad, usually because someone has died or left them, and they gradually become weak and sick. After Grandma died, Grandpa just pined away.
noun Ping-pong is another word for table tennis.
noun Pink is a colour that is a mixture of red and white.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pink

form.definition: noun A pin-up is a picture of a very attractive person or a famous person, such as a movie star or rock artist, that someone puts up on a wall. Most teenagers' rooms are plastered with pin-ups of their idols of the moment. She objected to the pornographic pin-ups in the locker area.

noun A pioneer is one of the first people to settle in a new country or area, often under harsh conditions. The pioneer James Ruse was granted an acre of land at Rose Hill in 1789. He was Australia's first independent farmer.
noun A pioneer in a particular activity is one of the first people to get involved in it. Victor Chang was a pioneer in Australian heart surgery.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pioneer They are pioneering a new approach to the problem.

form.definition: adjective If someone is pious, they are very religious and devout.
noun Pips are the small hard seeds that you find in some fruits, such as the apple, pear or mandarin.
give you the pip In informal language, if you say that someone gives you the pip, you mean that they irritate you.
pips The pips on the radio or telephone are a series of short high-pitched beeps that are used as a time signal.

noun A pipe is a hollow tube which is used to carry liquids or gases from one place to another. Our house was flooded when one of the pipes burst during winter. Be careful that you don't damage the gas pipes.
noun A pipe is a simple musical instrument consisting of a hollow tube that you blow down, with holes in its side that you cover with your fingers to produce different notes.

noun Some people smoke tobacco in a pipe. It consists of a hollow tube which leads to a round bowl for the tobacco. I'm glad you've got rid of that smelly old pipe. Smoking of cigarettes only is permittedno cigars or pipes, please.
pipe down In informal language, if you tell someone to pipe down, you want them to stop making so much noise.

pipe up In informal language, if you say someone pipes up, you mean that they suddenly say something although they've been quiet before. Some of you may be reluctant to pipe up in front of a lot of other people, but don't be nervous.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pipe He piped the water from the dam up to the house.

form.definition: noun A pirate is a sailor who attacks other ships at sea and steals their cargo. This happened often in the past, and still goes on in and near the China Sea.
verb If someone pirates something that someone else has invented, designed or composed, they steal that person's ideas and use them without paying a royalty.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun piracy (piracies)

form.definition: noun A pistol is a small gun. It has a short barrel and is usually kept in a holster.
noun A piston is a part of an engine consisting of a short cylinder that moves up and down or backwards and forwards inside another cylinder. It causes the other parts of the engine to move.
noun A pit is a large hole in the ground, usually dug for a purpose, such as mining. The miners are down in the pit digging out a new seam.

pit your wits If you pit your wits against someone, you try to beat them by using your intelligence or cunning. Pit your wits against your friends in our popular weekly quizes. He pitted his wits against his rival in a bid to win promotion.

the pits In informal language, if you say that something is the pits, you mean that it is very bad and unpleasant. The food in the canteen here is the pits. Having to stay in on a day like this is the pits.
noun A pitch is an area of land that is marked off for playing a sport such as hockey, football or cricket.
noun The pitch of a sound is how high or low it is. Carla's voice rose to a higher pitch as she became excited.
noun Pitch is also the amount that something slopes. The road which leads up to the cottage has a very steep pitch.
verb If you pitch something such as a ball, you throw it quite hard at a particular target. Steve pitched the ball straight at the stumps.
verb If you pitch a tent, you set it up so that it is upright and ready to be used. We pitched our tents beside the stream.
pitch in In informal language, if you say you pitch in, you mean that you join in an activity and help someone to do it. If we all pitch in, we'll be finished by lunchtime.

adjective If it is pitch-dark, there is no light at all and you can't see anything. When the power failed it was pitch-dark until Moira struck a match. The night was pitch-darkeven the moon was hidden by clouds.

noun A pitfall involved in doing something is a possible negative consequence or unforeseen danger if you aren't very careful. The plan seems good, but what are the pitfalls? One of the pitfalls of training is the temptation to overdo it.

noun Pith is a fibrous substance that is found in plants, for example in citrus fruits, between the peel and the juicy flesh of the fruit. ... WORD FAMILY adjective pithy (pithier, pithiest) Her comments are rather pithyshe doesn't waste words.

adjective If someone or something is pitiful, you feel sorry for them because the situation is so sad. Rosita lost all her family and possessions in the fireit's pitiful. The sick animal gave a pitiful whimper.
adjective If something is pitiful, it is completely inadequate. He gave some pitiful excuse for his behaviour. The whole family has to live on her pitiful pension.
noun A pittance is a very small amount of money. He works long hours for a pittance.

noun Pity is a feeling of great sympathy or sorrow that you feel for someone because of their unfortunate circumstances. Everyone feels pity for that poor girl whose mother was killed in the accident.

2 noun If you say that something is a pity, you mean that it's unfortunate or a shame. But usually it isn't something really serious or tragic. It's a pity you can't get off work and join us on Mondayit should be fun.
verb If you pity someone, you feel sorry for them. Who could fail to pity the refugees we see on our television screens every night? I pity Rod's poor mother, having to clear up after him.
noun A pivot is a central point on which something is balanced, or around which it turns.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pivot The bar is pivoted on this piece of metal.

dictionary.entry: Pl\times,0\ abbreviation for Place. It is usually used when you write an address. ...17 Rosevale Pl.

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say you placate someone who is angry, you mean that you manage to calm them down or give them something to make them happy again.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is appease.

form.definition: noun A place is any area of space. Is there a place where I can dump these books? Her leg was broken in two places.

noun A place is somewhere where you can go that is known by a particular name, such as a shop, a town or a country. Is Myer's the best place to buy furniture? She lives in a little place called Rendezvous Creek. Have you tried that new Thai place on King Street?
noun A place in something such as a book or essay is a particular part of it. You can look at my book but don't lose my place, please. I marked several places where your meaning isn't clear.
noun Someone's or something's place is the spot where they usually are. Who's been sitting in my place? Please put everything back in its proper place.
noun Your place of birth is where you were born. Your place of work is where you work.

noun Someone's or something's place in the world or in society is their particular situation or position in it. Evonne Goolagong has a place in history as the first Aboriginal woman to win the tennis championships at Wimbledon.
noun In informal language, someone's place is the house or unit where they live. Let's go over to my place. Nice place you've got here.

noun In a race or competition, your place is the position that you come in the order of finishing or of merit. I bet on Viceroy for first place but the stupid horse didn't even make it in the first three! Vicky took fifth place in the piano competition.
noun A place at table is a setting for one person. I laid an extra place in case Charlie did turn up. This dinner service contains six places.
noun Place is also used in the names of some streets, especially if they surround a square or open area. ...Martin Place.
verb If you place something somewhere, you put it there carefully or on purpose. The waiter placed the wine on the table so we could have a good look at the bottle before he opened it.
in the first place (a) You can use in the first place to give the first of two or more reasons for something. In the first place, it's too expensive, and in the second place, we haven't got time.

(b) You can also use in the first place to refer to the original situation before something else happened. You can't expect perfect results if the fabric was badly damaged in the first place. I don't care if she's upsetI never wanted to come here in the first place.
take place If an event takes place, it happens. The concerts take place every two weeks during the summer.

If you take someone's place, you replace them or substitute for them. If something takes the place of something else, it replaces it or substitutes for it. Hazel will take my place at next week's meeting. In this variation on the recipe, mushrooms take the place of the capsicum.

adjective If someone is placid, they are calm and don't get upset easily. Evelyn has a much more placid nature than her volatile elder sister. I don't know how you can be so placid about the trouble that we're in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb placidly She continued placidly reading her book.

form.definition: noun A plague is an outbreak of a highly infectious disease that spreads quickly from one person to another. Authorities fear a plague of cholera in the overcrowded and unsanitary conditions of the camps.
noun A plague of animals, such as rats, mice or ants, is so many of them that you can't control them. If you leave food unwrapped you're inviting a plague of cockroaches.

verb If someone or something plagues you, they are annoying and you can't get rid of them. The kids have been plaguing me with questions about my trip. She has been plagued by a recurrent knee injury.
avoid like the plague If you avoid someone or something like the plague, you make absolutely sure that you never have anything to do with them.
noun A plain is a large flat area of land.
adjective If something is plain, it is one colour only. It is not patterned. A plain carpet will tend to show up any marks and stains. Do you want plain or lined paper?
adjective If something is plain, it is simple and without elaboration. You can dress up a plain outfit with colourful accessories. I'd like a plain omelette, without any filling.

adjective If something such as a statement or fact is plain, it is clear or obvious. It was plain that he wasn't interested. Have I made myself plain? This is not to happen again. They're rewriting the leaflets in plain English instead of legal jargon.
adjective If someone is plain, they are not very physically attractive. At school she was always rather plain and serious.

plain clothes If people such as police officers are in plain clothes, they are wearing ordinary clothes and not a uniform. There were several police in plain clothes among the crowd, hoping to catch the pickpockets in the act.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb plainly I could see the outline very plainly.[qr

dictionary.entry:
plaitplAt
verb If you plait something such as hair or rope, you weave at least three strands of it together. Alex plaited her hair quickly before she left for school.
... ANOTHER WORD for this is braid. ... WORD FAMILY noun plait She wore her hair in two plaits.

form.definition: noun A plan is a scheme to do something in a certain way. You work it out in advance to try and make sure that it will succeed. Shula worked out a plan for moving all the furniture without too much disruption. The plan is to stay in Sydney for three days and then move on to Brisbane.
noun A plan is also a sketch, outline or diagram which shows how something is or how it will be. The plan for the new building looks great. Make a plan before you write your essay.

verb If you plan something, you work out all the details in advance. I've planned each stage of the project. It's important to plan for your financial needs after retirement. The redecoration is planned to be complete this week.
verb If you plan to do something, you intend to do it. I'm planning to go to the beach this weekend. When do you plan to leave?

plans Your plans are what you intend doing. Have you any plans for the holiday weekend? 'Would you like to go to the movies on Saturday?' 'I'm sorry, I've already made plans.' That doesn't fit in with my plans.
noun A plane is a flat surface.
noun A plane is a tool which carpenters use to smooth the surface of wood.

noun A plane is a certain level at which a topic can be discussed. You've mentioned the national economy, Jim, but I'm talking on a different planeabout local issues such as the new factory and the eighty jobs it will create.
noun A planet is a large body in space which revolves around a star. The sun's planets are Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune and Pluto.
noun A plank is a long flat piece of wood. One of the planks in the floor has come loose.

noun A plant is any living thing that is not an animal. It does not move around in search of food. Most plants grow in the earth and have roots, a stem and leaves. We went to the garden centre to buy some plants for our garden. These plants grow very well indoors.
verb If you plant seeds, you put them in the earth so that they can grow. Where shall we plant this bush? This year I've decided to plant carrots and lettuce.

verb If you plant something somewhere, you put it or fix it there. Ten-Hu planted himself squarely in front of the door. Anna managed to plant the idea of taking a holiday in his mind. She claimed that the drugs had been planted on her.
noun A plant is a factory. Hasan is doing shift work at the car plant.
noun Plant is large machinery and equipment collectively. Building contractors often hire the plant they need for each stage of the project. HEAVY PLANT CROSSING
noun A plaque is a flat piece of metal or stone with writing on it that is attached to a wall or monument in memory of a person or event.
noun Plaque is a substance that forms on your teeth. Harmful bacteria can grow in it.
noun Plaster is a mixture of lime, sand and water which hardens when it dries. It is used to line the inside walls and the ceilings of houses and other buildings.
noun A plaster is a dressing that you put on a minor cut or burn. It has a small patch of gauze and adhesive strips so that you can stick it to your body and peel it off again.

verb If you plaster something somewhere, you apply a lot of it rather carelessly. Don't plaster the icing over the caketry to spread it evenly. Her face was plastered with make-up. The walls were plastered with posters advertising the concert.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb plaster The walls still need to be plastered and decorated.noun plasterer George is a good plastererhe always does a professional job.adjective See plastered.

form.definition: verb In informal language, if you say someone is plastered, you mean that they're very drunk. Maria hadn't eaten anything all day so she ended up getting absolutely plastered at the wedding.

noun Plastic is a synthetic chemical compound which can be used to make many different objects. This dish isn't glassit's made of plastic, so it won't break as easily. Many different plastics have been developed in the twentieth century.

noun In informal language, people sometimes call credit cards plastic or plastic money. Do not confuse this with the Australian banknotes which are made of plastic. I'm broke and don't get paid till ThursdayI'll have to put it on the plastic.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective plastic ...a plastic bag. ...a plastic raincoat.

form.definition: Plastic surgery is surgery to reconstruct parts of someone's body after they've been injured, or to make them look more attractive. Ranlee's face was badly burned, but she had plastic surgery and now you'd hardly notice.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun plastic surgeon

form.definition: noun A plate is a flat dish for food. She stacked the dirty plates in the dishwasher. I buttered the roll on my side plate. Plastic or paper plates are more practical for a picnic.
noun If someone asks you to bring a plate to a social event, they want you to bring some food that you can share with the other people there.
noun A plate is a small flat piece of metal with writing on it. The plate on the door said 'Evan Stansgate'. This plate marks the spot where the old fire station used to be.
noun A plate is a piece of plastic, usually with false teeth or orthodontic wires attached, which is specially moulded to fit the roof of someone's mouth.
noun In a book, a plate is an illustration that takes up a whole page. The textbook has line drawings throughout and 24 four-colour plates in the middle. See Plate 16.
verb If metal is plated, it is covered with a thin layer of silver or gold. You have to be careful with cutlery that's been plated with silverthe silver sometimes wears off.

have a lot on your plate In informal language, if you say you have a lot on your plate, you mean that you are very busy and you have a great deal to cope with. I can't take on any more at the momentI've got enough on my plate as it is.
noun A plateau is an area of flat land high up among hills or mountains. The Atherton Tableland is a well-known plateau in the Great Dividing Range in northern Queensland.

noun A platform is a small raised area on which you can stand or place something, often in order to be seen more easily. He got up on the platform in the hall to make his farewell speech. The drill is mounted on a platform to hold it absolutely steady.

noun A platform at a railway station is the raised area beside the tracks, where you get on or off a train. I could see Irma standing at the far end of the platform to meet me. Our train goes from platform 12.

noun A platter is a large plate made of china or wood. It is used to serve food such as cold meats or cheese. People take the food they want from it and put it onto their own plates. After the dessert they served a cheese platter.
noun A platypus is an Australian animal with webbed feet and a bill like that of a duck. Like echidnas, they lay eggs and feed their young with their own milkthey are monotremes.

adjective If something is plausible, it seems likely to be true. It is not difficult to believe. You'll have to come up with a more plausible excuse than that. The most plausible explanation is that they'd already been and gone before we got there.
verb When children play, they have fun and enjoy themselves. Nino and Carmen are playing with the kids next door. Why don't you play with your new fire engine? Don't be meanlet Laura play too.

verb If you play a sport or a game, you take part in it. Co-Van plays football for his school. I don't play as much sport as I used to. I hurt my knee and couldn't play for a month. Do you know how to play bridge?
verb If you play a musical instrument, you produce music with it. Can you play the piano? Leyla plays the saxophone in a band.
verb If an actor plays a part in a movie or a play, they act that role. They pretend to be a particular character. Who is going to play Lady Macbeth? I'm fed up with playing the hero's girlfriend.
verb If you play a joke on someone, you trick them for fun. That was a rotten trick to play on the kids.
noun A play is a story which is performed by actors. We all really enjoyed the puppet play. Have you seen David Williamson's new play?
play at (a) If you play at something, you don't take what you're doing very seriously. She played at running her own business, but she never worked hard enough to be a success.
(b) If you ask someone what they're playing at, you're asking them angrily what they're doing or what they mean by it. What the hell are you playing at, upsetting my son like that?

play along If you play along with someone, you pretend to agree with them and do what they want. I'll play along with him for the moment just to see what he's planning. With the mugger holding a knife to my back, I was forced to play along.
play down If you play something down, you pretend to other people that it is less important or serious than it really is. The Prime Minister tried to play down the diplomatic row.
play up (a) If children play up, they behave badly. The kids tend to play up with a new babysitter.
(b) If a machine or piece of equipment plays up, it doesn't work properly. This damn dishwasher is playing up again.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun player Several players were injured in the first half of the match.adjective playful The puppies were frisky and playful. She gave me a playful pinch.adverb playfully

form.definition: noun A playground is an area of land set aside for children to play in. It often has swings and climbing equipment.
noun A playwright is someone who writes plays for actors to perform.
noun A plea is an emotional request. Sydney City Mission sent out a plea for donations to help the street kids at Christmas. She ignored his pleas and left.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See plead.

form.definition: verb If you plead with someone to do something, you ask them in a very emotional way to do it because it is very important to you that they should do it. She pleaded with her husband not to drive home on the icy roads.
verb In a court of law the defendant has to say whether they wish to plead guilty or not guilty to the crime with which they are charged. 'How do you plead?' 'Not guilty.'

adjective If something is pleasant, it is nice and agreeable. We spent a pleasant day at the beach. Paula's got a very pleasant personality. It made a pleasant change not to have to do the housework. What a pleasant surprise!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb pleasantly She smiled at us pleasantly. I was pleasantly surprised to see him.

form.definition: adverb You use please to make a request or order sound more polite. I'd like six bananas, please. Move over, please, and make room for the others. PLEASE DO NOT TOUCH
adverb You also use please to be polite in other ways. Please don't worry about it. 'Would you like some cake?' 'Yes, please.' 'Can I help you with that?' 'Please.' 'May I sit here?' 'Please do.'
verb If something pleases you, it gives you pleasure and makes you happy. His success pleased his parents.

please yourself People sometimes say please yourself quite abruptly and rudely if they think you have rejected them when they were trying to be nice to you. 'Would you like to come to the movies with us?' 'Tonight I have to help my mother.' 'OK, please yourself.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pleased I was very pleased to hear you'd done so well.adjective pleasing She has a very pleasing voice. Ming has made pleasing progress this term.

form.definition: noun Pleasure is a feeling of happiness or enjoyment. Your news gave me great pleasure. His pleasure at his success was obvious. She seemed to take pleasure in pointing out my mistake.
it's a pleasure to meet you It's a pleasure to meet you is a formal expression that people sometimes use when they are introduced to someone for the first time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pleasurable It was a very pleasurable sensation.[qr

dictionary.entry:
pleatpli:t
noun A pleat is a permanent fold in a piece of material which is either pressed or stitched into place. I hate ironing this skirtit's got so many pleats!
... WORD FAMILY adjective pleated ...a pleated skirt.

form.definition: noun In rather formal language, a pledge is a solemn promise to do something. The Prime Minister seems to have forgotten his pledge to reduce hospital waiting lists.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pledged She pledged that she would carry out her father's ambition.

form.definition: pronoun If there is plenty of something, there is easily enough or more than is needed. There's plenty of timewe don't have to leave for another twenty minutes. Don't buy any more milkwe've still got plenty. Don't grabthere's plenty for everyone.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective plentiful They have access to a plentiful supply of fresh water.

form.definition: adjective If something is pliable, you can move or bend it easily. You've got to be fast with this gluethe mixture is pliable for only two minutes before it sets.
adjective If someone is pliable, they are easily influenced by other people. Jo is a very pliable child, and the older ones led her astray.[qr

dictionary.entry:
pliers`pla:I@z
noun You use pliers to bend or cut wire or to pull out nails. ...a pair of pliers. I'll need some pliers to pull out this rusty nail.

form.definition: noun In rather formal language, a plight is a bad or serious situation. The government has done nothing to relieve the plight of small businesses during the recession. She had no-one to turn to in her plight.
verb If you plod in a certain direction, you walk slowly and heavily, perhaps because you are tired or you have a long way to go. We plodded off along the road towards the nearest town.
verb If you plod through your work, you keep at it even though you find it very boring. I'll just keep plodding on sorting out all these old papers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun plodder Carlos is a bit of a plodder at school not really bright, but he works hard.

form.definition: verb If you plonk something somewhere, you put it down roughly and carelessly. Gloria plonked her bag on the table. 'Where do you want these?' 'Oh, just plonk them down over there.' He plonked himself right in front of the fire and took all the heat.
noun A plonk is a heavy dull sound. The book fell over with a plonk.
noun In informal language, plonk is cheap wine. Don't forget to bring a bottle of plonk to the party, will you?

dictionary.entry:
plotplOtplotsplottedplotting 1a noun A plot is a secret plan to do something, often something illegal. Their plot to take control of the company failed. Police were warned about
verb If someone plots to do something, they plan secretly to do it. A small group of conspirators was plotting to overthrow the government. I'm sure she's plotting to get my job.
noun The plot in a book, movie or play is the story of what happens. I found the plot quite confusingit was a murder mystery, and I couldn't follow it at all!
noun A plot is a small piece of land.
verb If you plot the development of something, you follow its progress by marking it on a graph or diagram. The price fluctuations can be plotted on a graph.
... WORD FAMILY noun plotter Most of the plotters were arrested and imprisoned.

form.definition: noun A plough is a piece of farm equipment which is attached to the back of a tractor and used to turn over the soil before crops are planted.
verb When a farmer ploughs a paddock, they turn over the soil using a plough.

verb If something such as a car ploughs into something else, it smashes into it. Yolanda lost control on the icy roads and ploughed into a telegraph pole. The bus ploughed through the hedge and ended up on its side.

verb If you plough through something, you keep trying to make progress even though it is difficult and boring. Sudha was still ploughing through the accounts at midnight. It's not exactly an easy readI ploughed through the first hundred pages and then gave up.

verb If someone ploughs money into a business, they continue to finance it in the hope that it will be profitable in the end. Zhang has ploughed so much money into his business that he can't give up now. For the first three years we drew a pittance and ploughed back nearly everything we made.
noun A ploy is a way of behaving that somebody uses in order to achieve a particular result that they want. Bursting into tears was an obvious ploy to gain my sympathy.
verb If you pluck a flower or fruit from a plant, you pull it off the plant. She plucked a lemon from the tree.
adjective If someone is plucky, they are rather brave and daring in trying hard to achieve something. She was a plucky, spirited girl, and wouldn't let obstacles stand in her way.[qr
noun A plug is a device with two or three prongs which connects the lead of an electrical appliance to the power supply. The prongs on the plug fit into a power point.
noun A plug is a round piece of rubber which you put into the hole at the bottom of a sink or bath when you want to stop the water from pouring away.
verb If you plug a hole or a crack, you put something in it to fill it up. The builder plugged the holes with putty.
noun A plug is a free announcement or advertisement, especially on the radio. Can I put in a plug for our bush danceit's next Saturday, and all the money goes to charity.
verb In informal language, if you say you plug for something, you mean that you campaign enthusiastically for it. The netball association is plugging for extra courts to be built.
noun A plughole is the hole at the bottom of a sink or bath through which the water pours away.
noun A plumber is someone whose job is to install and repair water pipes and drainage or sewerage systems.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun plumbing There's something wrong with the plumbingthe cistern keeps gurgling.

form.definition: verb If something such as an aeroplane plummets, it falls through the air towards the ground at great speed. The plane lost power and plummeted to the ground. The wounded bird plummeted from the sky.
verb If prices plummet, they suddenly become very much lower. The price of gold plummeted on world markets yesterday.
adjective If someone is plump, they are rather fat. She was plump as a child, and now she's grossly overweight.
plump up If you plump up a cushion or pillow, you hit and shake it to make it come back into shape after it's been squashed. Lakshmi plumped up the lounge room cushions before the guests arrived.
verb If something plunges, if falls dramatically, sometimes from a great height. The car plunged over the cliff. She paused for a minute on the diving board, and then plunged into the water.
verb If an amount plunges, it decreases dramatically. In the desert temperatures can plunge overnight.

verb If you plunge somewhere, you put yourself there dramatically and decisively. All I want now is to plunge into a hot shower. He plunged back into the burning building to try and rescue the child. Inga plunged into her work with fresh enthusiasm.
verb If you plunge something somewhere, you thrust it there quickly and violently. The blacksmith plunged the hot iron into the water.
take the plunge If you take the plunge, you begin to do something you have been meaning to do for a long time but hesitated to start.
adjective In grammar, plural means that a word refers to more than one person or thing. 'Clothes' is a plural noun. What is the plural form of 'this'?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun plural The plural of 'child' is 'children'.

form.definition: preposition Plus is used to show that one number or quantity is added to something else. In writing mathematical equations the plus sign (+) is used to represent this word, as in '2 + 3 ;eq 5'. Two plus three equals five. I've got ten dollars left, plus the five Polly owes me, so that makes fifteen.

adjective You can use plus in front of a number to show that it is more than zero. It is positive. In writing, the plus sign (+) is usually used instead of the word 'plus'. Minus three squared equals plus nine.
conjunction Plus can be used to add another statement or reason that backs up what you've already said. Let's invite Kenhe's a nice person, plus he's been a bit lonely lately.
noun In informal language, a plus is an advantage in a situation. Good weather is a definite plus for a holiday.

adjective If something is plush, it is very luxurious and probably expensive. Their house, and everything in it, is extremely plush. The wedding reception was held at one of the town's plushest hotels.

verb If you ply someone with food or drink, you keep giving them more and more of it. Animesh plied his guests with delicious savouries. I suspected she was plying me with drink in the hope that I would become indiscreet.

verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone plies a trade, you mean that they work regularly at a particular activity to make money. Hawkers ply their trade outside the hotel. Since the accident he has been unable to ply his usual trade.
noun Ply refers to the number of strands or layers that compose something. Garments for babies are often knitted in three-ply yarn. Be sure and buy two-ply toilet paper.
noun Plywood is a building material made up of thin layers of wood which are stuck together.
abbreviation for post meridiem, which is a Latin phrase meaning 'after noon'. The meeting will begin promptly at 7.00 p.m.
noun Pneumonia is a serious illness caused by an inflammation of the lungs which makes it difficult to breathe.
abbreviation for post office.
verb If you poach food, you cook it in water just below boiling point. I'm going to poach two eggs for breakfast.
verb If someone poaches game animals or fish, they catch them illegally when they don't have the right to do so.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun poacher Elephants are being hunted to the point of extinction by poachers.

form.definition: noun A pocket is a piece or fold of material which is sewn on the inside or outside of a garment to form a sort of pouch which you can keep things in. I always keep a clean handkerchief in my pocket.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pocket Daria pocketed the ring before anyone saw her.

form.definition: noun Pocket money is a small amount of money that some parents give to their children, usually once a week, for them to buy small items for themselves. I give each of my children $5 pocket money a week.
noun A pod is a long, narrow seed container that grows on plants such as peas and beans.
adjective If someone is podgy, they are rather fat and unattractive. He's looking a bit podgy since he's taken to visiting the club every night.
noun A poem is a piece of imaginative writing which is structured a certain way, with short lines that often follow a pattern of rhythm or rhyme.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See poetry. noun poet

form.definition: noun Poetry is poems in general, or the class of literature consisting of poems. Have you read any Australian poetry? Which do you prefer, poetry or drama?
noun Poetry can also refer to a beautiful or pleasing quality that people notice in something. The film captured the poetry of their dancing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective poetic

form.definition: noun A point is an exact location in space. It has no dimensions or size. A straight line is the shortest distance between two points. The point where the two axes intersect is called the origin.
noun A point is a sharply tapering part of something. The point on this pencil is blunt.
noun A point is a particular stage in the development of something or in the course of things happening. At this point the baby began to cry. I'd reached a point where I just couldn't go on.

noun A point is something that adds to your argument or to the discussion on a subject. It is one idea or thought. I'd like to make one further point. That's trueyou have a good point there. I take your point, but there are other issues to consider.
noun In some games, a point is a unit of scoring. You get five points for a correct answer.
noun A point is a headland that sticks out into a bay.

verb If you point at something, you hold out your finger in the direction that you want people to look. The customer pointed at the chairs she wanted to buy. Can you point to your country on this map? My mother taught me that it's rude to point.
verb If you point something in a certain direction, you hold it so that it faces that way. The raider kept his gun pointed at the hostage.
no point If you say that there is no point doing something, you mean that doing it will not be any use. There's no point calling nowthey'll have already left. Is there any point asking him again?

point of view (a) A person's point of view is the opinion or attitude that they have about a particular matter. You will have a chance to express your point of view during the meeting. The letters to the editor often contain some interesting points of view.

(b) If you consider something from a particular point of view, you assess it on the basis of one aspect of a situation. From a legal point of view, I see no problem with your suggestion. What do you think of my idea from the point of view of improving sales?
form.note: ... NOTEthat the plural of this is points of view.

form.definition: point out If you point something out to someone, you draw their attention to it. She pointed out several local beauty spots on the map. I'd just like to point out that it was my idea.
point to If something points to a certain state of affairs, it indicates that that is the way things probably are. The discovery of a petrol can in the ruins pointed to arson.
the point In a discussion or conversation, the point is the main idea in what you're saying. That's just the pointJill can't go with you because she's sick. Come on, get to the point!
to the point If what you say is to the point, it is relevant and doesn't use too many words. Your essay was clear and to the pointwell done!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pointed He picked up the rubbish with a pointed stick.

form.definition: adverb If you say something point-blank, you say it straight out without any pretence at being polite. She asked him point-blank if he had taken her wallet.
adjective If you fire a gun at point-blank range, you fire it very close to your target.

adjective If an action is pointless, it is a waste of time because it won't achieve anything. Students get bored with pointless exercises that have no relevance to real life. Without him life seemed pointless.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pointlessness

form.definition: verb If you poise something somewhere, you position it carefully or balance it there. I poised the pile of books on one of the empty desks.
noun If you have poise, you behave in a confident and dignified manner, even when you are under pressure. Terry handled the interview with such poise that she was offered the job.
noun Poison is any substance which harms or kills you if you absorb it into your body. All bottles containing poison should be kept in a locked cupboard.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb poison He claimed his wife was trying to poison him.adjective poisonous ...a poisonous snake. ...poisonous plants.

form.definition: verb If you poke someone or something, you push or jab them with your finger or with something you hold in your hand. Keith poked the spider with a stick to see if it was still alive. Susie poked suspiciously at her food with her fork.
verb If you poke something somewhere, you push it there, usually through a narrow opening. He poked the letter under the door.
verb If something pokes out, it shows or appears from behind something else. Naomi poked her head around the corner and offered us a cup of tea.
poke fun at If you poke fun at someone, you make fun of them. You laugh at them or tell a joke about them. I'm sick of the others at work poking fun at my accent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun poke Give me a poke if I fall asleep during the movie.

form.definition: 1 noun Poker is a card game that people play to win money. Taylor lost $200 playing poker last night.
2 poker machine A poker machine is a gambling machine. You operate it by putting coins into it and pulling the handle.
form.note: ... AN INFORMAL WORD for these machines is pokies.

form.definition: adjective If something such as a room is poky, it is small and cramped. The whole family lives in a poky two-room unit.
noun A pole is a long round piece of wood or metal which stands upright and supports something. The car crashed into a telegraph pole. ...a flag pole.
Pole A Pole is someone who comes from Poland.
poles apart If you say two people are poles apart, you mean that their views on a certain topic are completely different. My sister and I are poles apart when it comes to bringing up our kids.
up the pole In informal language, if you say you are up the pole, you mean that you're in an awkward or difficult situation. She couldn't lend us her car so we were really up the pole.
noun The police are the men and women whose job is to protect people and their property from crime and to catch and arrest criminals. There's been a break-inwill someone call the police?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective police ...the police service. ...a police officer.noun policeman (policemen) noun policewoman (policewomen)

form.definition: noun A policy is a basic plan about what to do that has been agreed on by a group of people. It is the policy of this store not to give cash refunds. What is the Liberal policy on gun control?

noun An insurance policy is an official document which sets out the details of the items that are insured, and any special conditions. Most policies exclude pre-existing medical conditions. Be sure to read the policy carefully and check it suits your needs.
noun Polio is a disease which can leave sufferers with permanently paralysed limbs. These days most people are vaccinated against polio when they are babies.
form.note: ... NOTEthat this is a shortened form of poliomyelitis.

form.definition: noun Polish is a paste or liquid which you can rub over objects in order to improve their appearance by making them shine. ...shoe polish. ...silver polish. ...floor polish.
verb If you polish something, you make it shine by rubbing it with a cloth and usually with polish.
2 noun If someone has polish, they are sophisticated and experienced. We need someone with a bit more polish for the receptionist's job.
3 polish off In informal language, if you say you polish something off, you mean that you finish it. I'm going to try and polish off this work today. Who polished off the chocolate cake?
adjective If someone or something comes from Poland, you describe them as Polish.
noun Polish is the language of Poland.

adjective If you are polite, you have good manners and do what is socially acceptable. Fiona's a polite childshe always offers a seat to older people on the bus. It's not polite to reach across people at table.
noun Polite also means civil or courteous. Even though she was very angry she tried to remain polite.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is impolite or rude. ... WORD FAMILY adverb politely noun politeness

form.definition: noun A politician is a member of parliament or someone whose job is in politics. ...a Labor politician. a Liberal politician.

noun Politics refers to the business of governing a country, the people involved in it and all the things that relate to it. Imran's doing law at university, but he wants to get into politics eventually.
noun Someone's politics are their beliefs about how a country should be governed. I like Alberto, but I don't agree with his politics.

noun Politics also refers to the strategies and activities that people use in order to gain power in any organisation. Raoul's not really interested in the politics of the departmentthat's probably why he's never been promoted.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See politician. adjective political

form.definition: noun A poll is a survey in which people are asked their opinion about something, such as whether they are in favour of a particular person or policy. The Prime Minister has done very badly in the latest opinion poll.
verb If someone polls a certain number of votes in an election, they receive that number of votes. Early returns show that the Government is polling very badly.
the polls The polls are the official government elections. The Prime Minister said that the only result that counts is the final result at the polls. Australia goes to the polls next month.
noun Pollen is a fine powder produced in flowers that causes other flowers to produce seeds after it is carried to them, for example by the wind or by insects.

verb If something pollutes the environment, it makes the earth, water or air so dirty that it's dangerous for humans or animals. Our waterways have been polluted by industrial wastethe clean-up operation will take years. ... WORD FAMILY noun pollution
noun Polo is a game played by two teams riding on horses. They try to score points by hitting a ball into the goal with a long-handled wooden stick.
noun In informal language, a pommy is someone from England. Australians sometimes use this word as a joke or an insult.
form.note: ... ANOTHER FORM of this is pom. ... WORD FAMILY adjective pommy

form.definition: adjective If someone is pompous, they speak and behave in a very serious and formal way and they think they are much more important than they really are. What a pompous idiot! Who does he think he is?
noun A pond is a small area of water. Ben built a pond for his fish in the backyard.
verb In rather formal language, if you say you ponder, you mean that you think very carefully about something. After this dreadful setback, he's pondering whether to go ahead with the project at all.
noun In informal language, a pong is an unpleasant smell. What on earth is that dreadful pong? It smells like rotting cabbage!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pong Phew! This cheese really pongs!

form.definition: noun A pony is a small type of horse.

noun If you have your hair in a ponytail, it is pulled back from your face and held by an elastic band or ribbon at the back of your head. The hair hangs loose from where it is tied and resembles a horse's tail.
noun Poo is an informal word that children sometimes use for faeces.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is pooh. ... WORD FAMILY verb poo

form.definition: interjection In informal language, people sometimes use pooh to express disgust or disappointment. Pooh, where's that smell coming from? Oh pooh, here he is againI can't get rid of him.
noun A pool is a small area of water or other liquid. There were pools of water all over the lawn after the heavy rain.
noun A pool is also a swimming pool.
verb If a group of people pool their resources, they combine them so that they can be used by the entire group. Members of a family travelling together may pool their duty free allowances.

noun A pool is a resource used by a group of people. It is a supply or a service which they all share. I'm a member of a car poolI share the driving with a few other parents from my daughter's school.
noun Pool is also a game like billiards in which the players use a cue to hit coloured balls into holes.

adjective If someone is poor, they have very little money or resources. When I was a poor student, I worked in a bar to pay the rent. Naturally many people seek to migrate from poor countries to more prosperous ones.

adjective If something is poor, it is of bad quality. He's in poor health. Nadia's exam results were very poor. She mumbled some poor excuse for being late. They made a poor attempt at repairing the damage.
adjective If you refer to someone as poor, you are expressing sympathy for them. Poor Jane's lost her job. You poor thing, it must be really painful.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See poverty. noun poor There is a vast gulf between rich and poor in our society.

form.definition: noun Pop is the style of music, usually consisting of short songs, that is popular with young people.
noun A pop is a short loud sound. The cork came out of the bottle with a pop.
verb If something such as a balloon or a bubble pops, it bursts.

verb In informal language, if you say you pop somewhere, you mean you go there for a short time. Maritza popped into her neighbour's house to get some flour. I'm just popping down to the shops for some groceries.

verb In informal language, if you say you pop something somewhere, you mean you put it there quickly or casually. Before Ali's mother could stop him, he popped another lolly into his mouth. Pop the pie under the grill for five minutes to brown the crust.
noun The Pope is the head of the Roman Catholic church. He lives in the Vatican in Rome.

adjective If someone or something is popular, they are liked by many people. She is one of the most popular girls in the class. Roast turkey is still a popular Christmas dish. You won't be very popular if you ask them to work back.

adjective Popular beliefs or attitudes are those which are held by a large number of people. He exactly fits the popular image of the absent-minded professor. It's a popular misconception that starch is fattening.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun popularity

form.definition: verb If people populate an area, they live there. This suburb is heavily populated by students because it is close to the university.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun population Australia's population is more than 18 million.

form.definition: noun A porch is a covered area at the entrance to a building. Leave your umbrella on the porch.
noun Pores are the small holes in your skin through which you sweat. Use a non-greasy cleansing lotion to unclog your facial pores.
pore over If you pore over books or documents, you study them carefully. He was poring over the map, working out the best route to take. She spends hours in her room poring over old comics.
noun Pork is meat from a pig.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pork ...pork sausages.

form.definition: noun Pornography is material such as writing, pictures or film which describes or shows sexual acts in a way intended to cause sexual arousal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pornographic

form.definition: adjective If something is porous, it will allow water to pass through it. Unfortunately that pottery vase is porousyou can only put dried flowers in it.
noun Porridge is a food made from oats. It is usually eaten hot for breakfast, with milk and sugar.
noun A port is a seaside town with a harbour. This is used as the first word in many Australian place names. The captain decided to take shelter in the nearest port. Quang was born at Port Kembla.
noun A port is also the actual harbour area where ships load and unload.
adjective The port side of a ship or aeroplane is its left side. The opposite of this is starboard.
adjective If a machine is portable, it is made to be easy to carry. ...a portable TV. ...a portable radio.
noun A porter is someone whose job is to look after the entrance of a hotel or other large reception area.
noun A porter is someone whose job is to carry people's luggage at a railway station, airport or hotel.
noun The portfolio of a government minister is the set of responsibilities which their position involves. He took over the health portfolio only a month ago.

noun A portion is an amount of something, especially food, that is allocated or served to one person. She divided the cheesecake into six portions. A portion of hot chips, please. The food is excellent and the portions are generous. We do children's portions at half price.

noun In rather formal language, a portion of something is a part or a certain amount of it. A good portion of the book relates to her years in New Guinea. The first portion of the film is rather slow.
noun A portrait is a picture of someone that shows what they look like. The boardroom is lined with portraits of previous chairmen.
noun A portrait of something is a written or spoken description of it. The biography paints an unflattering portrait of its subject. I recognised Tom at once from the portrait in his sister's letter.
verb If you portray someone in a certain way, you represent them as being like that, either in speech, or in a book, movie or play. In the book, Mary was portrayed as a rather weak character.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun portrayal Mel Gibson gave an excellent portrayal of Hamlet's anguish.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something comes from Portugal, you describe them as Portuguese.
noun Portuguese is the language of Portugal.

verb If you pose for a photograph, you stand in a particular way or in a particular place so that someone can take a picture of you. The bride and groom posed outside the church. Pirjo refused to pose topless.
verb If someone poses as someone else, they pretend to be that person. The attacker apparently gained access to the woman's flat by posing as an insurance salesman.
verb In rather formal language, if you say someone poses a question, you mean they ask one.
verb If something poses a problem or a threat, it causes one. Her refusal posed us a dilemma. The virus can pose a serious danger to the elderly.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pose She struck a dramatic pose for the camera.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say something is posh, you mean it is smart and expensive. He lives in a posh flat in the centre of town. Why are you all dressed up in your posh suit?

noun The position of someone or something is the place where they are. It is their location. He radioed his position to the control room. I tried putting the lounge in a new position against the opposite wall. This diagram shows the positions of the fire exits.

noun Someone's position is the way they are occupying a placefor example, lying down or sitting. She was sitting in a cross-legged position. Artists' models have to be able to hold the same position for long periods.
