noun Your position in society or at work is your level of importance compared to other people. John is not in a position of authorityhe doesn't have a lot of influence. She used her position to get her own way.

noun Your position in a race or competition is where you are in relation to other competitors, especially before the final result. Kim did well in her gym competitionshe was in second position after the floor routine, and finished in third place overall.
noun Your position at a particular time is your situation or state. At the moment I'm in the fortunate position of having a bit of spare cash. Our financial position is a lot better than a year ago.

noun In formal language, a position is a job. I should like to apply for the position as clerk advertised in yesterday's newspaper. I'm sorry, the position has been filled. Why did you leave your last position?

in a position to If you are in a position to do something, you are able to do it or it is suitable for you to do it. Fortunately my father was in a position to lend me the money. He's in no position to complainit's largely his fault anyway. ... WORD FAMILY verb position Position the tiles carefully before gluing them.

adjective In rather informal language, if you say you are positive about something, you mean that you are certain or sure. The witness was positive that the car was a yellow Holden. Are you positive that you won't have any more?

verb If you feel positive about something, you are optimistic or enthusiastic. I'm not sure that I'll get the job, but it all looks quite positive. At first I was too tired to care, but after a rest I grew more positive.
adjective If you have a positive attitude, you concentrate on opportunities instead of problems. You've got to have a positive attitude if you're going to be a good salesperson.
adjective A positive reply to a question or statement shows agreement or approval. We're hoping for a positive reply from the bank about our loan.
adjective A positive result in something such as a medical test means that what was being checked for is present. The pregnancy test was positive.
adjective A positive number is greater than zero.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb positively He wasn't just abrupt, he was positively rude.

form.definition: verb In rather formal language, if you say that you possess something, you mean that you own it. It belongs to you. Excuse me, sir, do you possess a blue Toyota, numberplate IOU 345? I've never possessed a camera.
verb If you possess a quality or trait, you have it. It is characteristic of you. Vishal has overcome enormous difficultieshe possesses great determination.

verb If an emotion possesses someone, it overwhelms them and influences their whole outlook and actions. You must try not to let yourself be possessed by bitterness. What on earth possessed you to lie to your father like that?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See possession. adjective See possessive.

form.definition: noun Possession of something is owning or controlling it. Linane got possession of the ball, ran down the wing and scored.

in possession of If you are in possession of something, you have it. Your Honour, the court is in possession of some of his letters to the victim. He is no longer in full possession of his mental faculties.
possessions Your possessions are things that you own. Your household contents and other possessions can be insured for replacement value with this policy.
adjective If someone is possessive, they do not like sharing something that they own with anyone else.

adjective We also say a person is possessive if they want to control someone that they love and limit their relationships with other people. He's terribly possessive about his daughterhe refuses to allow her to go out with boys.
adjective If something is possible, it can be done. It's possible to fix the gearbox, but it will be expensive. Good morning, is it possible to speak to Mark Evans?
adjective If something is possible, it may happen. It's possible I'll be back early today. Further showers are possible over the next few days.
adjective If something is possible, it could be true or correct but you don't know for sure. It's possible that he's left already.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun possibility (possibilities) adverb possibly He's possibly the best player in the world. Could you possibly help me?

form.definition: noun A possum is an Australian animal that lives in trees and is active at night. It has long arms and legs, and a long tail.
noun Post is the system of collecting, transporting and delivering letters and parcels. The letter came by post.
noun Your post is the letters, parcels and circulars that are delivered to you.
verb If you post a letter or parcel, you take it to a post office or put it in a post box so that it can be delivered.

noun A post is also a piece of wood that stands upright and is usually used to support something. She tied her dog to the post outside the shop. ...a fence post. ...a gate post. b noun A post is also used to mark the end of a race. First past the post was Mr Bigwhat a great race!
noun A post in a company or organisation is a position or job in it. Neelam is about to take up a new post as marketing director in the company.
verb If you post something such as a notice or sign somewhere, you put or fix it there so that people can see it. The uni exam results were posted on the noticeboard in the quadrangle.
verb If a company posts an employee somewhere, they send them there to work for the company. Dion was posted to Sydney for four years.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun postage How much is the postage on this letter?adjective postal What is your postal address?

form.definition: noun A postal label is an adhesive label that you can buy at a post office to show that you have paid the correct postage for a letter or parcel. You stick it on the letter or parcel instead of stamps.
noun A postbox is a large container that stands on a street. You can put stamped letters and small parcels into it and they will be collected and delivered.
noun A postbox is also a small box, usually on a short pole at the front of your property, where letters are delivered to you.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is letterbox.

form.definition: noun A postcard is a flat rectangular card that you send to someone in the post instead of a letter. It usually has a picture on one side and space on the other side for a short message and the address and stamp. Don't forget to send me a postcard from Europe!
noun Your postcode is a group of numbers at the end of your address which shows the area or region where you live. Australia Post uses postcodes to help sort letters and parcels.
noun A poster is a large notice or colourful picture. Voula bought four travel posters to decorate the walls in her new flat. A poster advertising the fete was pinned on the school noticeboard.
noun People sometimes call their bottom their posterior.
noun Posterity means future generations of people. Our school has a good archive sectionwe feel it's important to keep a record for posterity.
adjective A postgraduate student is someone who already has one degree and is doing further study for a higher degree.
noun A postman is a man whose job is to deliver letters and parcels that people send by post.

noun A post-mortem is a medical examination of a dead person. It is done to find out what caused their death or to learn more about their disease. The cause of death is unknown, so the coroner has ordered a post-mortem.
noun A post office is a building where you can buy stamps and post letters and parcels. You can also pay telephone accounts, apply for Australian passports and collect tax and electoral forms there.
noun A post-office box is a small locked box which you can rent at a post office where your letters can be delivered.
verb If you postpone doing something that you had planned to do, you put it off until a later date. Could we postpone our meeting for an hour or so to give Sung time to get here?
form.note: ... A SIMILAR WORD is defer. ... WORD FAMILY noun postponement

form.definition: noun A postscript is a short message which you write at the very end of a letter, after you've signed your name. Usually it is something you forgot to write in the main letter or it's about something that happened after you wrote it. Gina's letter had a postscript which read 'PSdon't forget to give my love to Sam'.
form.note: ... THE ABBREVIATION for this is PS.

form.definition: noun A postscript is an additional piece of information about something that happened later. There's an interesting postscript to the storySofia did marry him in the end.
noun Your posture is the way you carry your body when you are standing or sitting. Hasan's posture is poorhis shoulders are always stooped.
noun A posy is a small bunch of flowers. The bridesmaids carried posies of white roses.

noun A pot is a dish which you use for cooking on top of the stove or in the oven. It can be made of many different materials such as aluminium, steel or earthenware. Throw a few more carrots into the pot.
noun The word pot is used to refer to many household containers which are used for a specific purpose. Dave made a fresh pot of tea. ...a pot of jam. ...a paint pot.
noun In gardening, a pot is a plant container. Don't forget to water my pots while I'm away, will you?
verb If you pot a plant, you put it into a pot.
noun In informal language, pot is another word for marijuana. Carlos told me he smokes pot, but he's never used hard drugs.

gone to pot In informal language, if you say someone or something has gone to pot, you mean that they've got into a very bad state. He's gone to pot since his wife diedhe just can't stand the loneliness. All my plans for the future went to pot when I failed my exams.
noun A potato is a very common vegetable which grows under the ground. The skin is red or brown and the inside is white.

hot potato In informal language, if you say a subject or issue is a hot potato, you mean that it has to be dealt with cautiously because many people feel very strongly about it. The party is reluctant to tackle the issue of gun controlit's too much of a hot potato.

adjective If something such as a drug is potent, it is very strong. A small amount of it has a big effect. This medicine is very potentbe sure and use it strictly as directed. The punch was more potent than I expected and I was soon quite tipsy.

noun Your potential is the best that you could do if you tried hard and practised. He is working well below his potential. b noun If you say that someone or something has potential, you mean that they could be very good in the future. This house has potential but we'd need to spend about $50 000 on renovations.

adjective A potential winner or potential leader is someone who may become a winner or leader in the future. Kimberley is training hard at gymnasticsshe's a potential Olympic athlete. I tried hard to be nice to Keira's boyfriend, as he was my potential son-in-law.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb potentially This is potentially the most significant discovery we have made.

form.definition: noun A pothole is a hole in the surface of a road. Drive slowly and be careful of the potholesyou can ruin your axle if you hit one.
noun A potter is a person who makes things such as mugs, bowls and vases out of clay.

verb If you potter, you spend time doing small and rather unimportant tasks. My father loves pottering in the garden. I got up fairly late on Saturday and pottered for a couple of hours before going out to the shops.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pottery He has a fine collection of Italian pottery.adjective pottery They put up a pottery plaque with their house number on it.

form.definition: noun A potty is a plastic or china bowl which is used instead of a toilet by a young child or by someone who is sick or infirm.

adjective In informal language, if you say someone is potty, you mean that they are eccentric or mad. She went potty in her old age and thought that the neighbours were persecuting her. This may seem a potty thing to do, but I think it'll work.

be potty about In informal language, if you say someone is potty about something, you mean that they like it very much and it's very important to them. Don't touch his roseshe's potty about them, and can't bear to have them damaged. Jamie's been potty about Ellen for weeks, but she's just not interested.[qr

dictionary.entry:
pouchpa:UtS
noun A pouch is a small bag. ...a tobacco pouch.
noun Female kangaroos, koalas and other marsupials have a pouch in which they carry their young. A little joey jumped out from its mother's pouch.
If you have pouches under your eyes, the skin there hangs in folds, often because you are very tired. She looked well, apart from the pouches under her eyes.

form.definition: noun Poultry refers to all the farm birds which are killed for people to eat, such as chickens, turkeys, ducks and geese.

verb If an animal pounces on something such as another animal or a person, it leaps at it, usually in order to kill it so that it can eat it. The lion pounced on the zebra. The cat sat watching the mouse, and suddenly pounced.

verb If you pounce on someone, you catch them unexpectedly. The boss was waiting at the door to pounce on anyone arriving late. She pounced on me at the end of the meeting and asked me to be on the committee.

verb If you pounce on a mistake that someone has made, you immediately take notice of it, and maybe get other people to take notice of it too. Make sure that your spelling is perfect, so they can't pounce on that.
noun The pound is the currency used in Britain and some other countries. It is made up of one hundred pence. He earns about six hundred pounds a week.
noun The pound is also a unit of weight used in Britain, the USA and some other English-speaking countries. It is equivalent to 454 grams.
noun A pound is a place where lost or stray dogs are taken. We got a new dog from the local pound.
noun A pound is a place where cars which have been illegally parked are taken. I parked on a clearway and by the time I got back my car had been towed to the pound.
verb If you pound something, you make a lot of noise by hitting it very hard. She pounded the table with her fist in anger. He pounded frantically at the locked door.
verb If you pound somewhere, you run there heavily and noisily. She pounded up the stairs and yelled at the kids to be quiet. A police officer came pounding round the corner in pursuit.
verb If your heart pounds, it beats very fast and noisily. I was so nervous that my heart began to pound. He flung himself over the finish with heart pounding and lungs bursting.

verb If you pour liquid, you let it run out of a container. I poured the syrup all over the pudding. The milk was sour, so I poured it down the drain. Can I pour you another glass of wine? The molten metal is poured into the moulds.

verb If it pours with rain, it rains very heavily. It was pouring with rain, so we decided to stay at home. At first it was only a light drizzle, but soon it began to pour. Outside the rain was pouring down, but we were snug.
verb If people pour somewhere, a lot of them go there quickly. The audience poured out of the hall at the end of the concert.
verb If you pour money or resources into a business or enterprise, you invest a large amount in an attempt to succeed. AAA Investments have poured more than $100 000 into the motor repair business.

pour in If things such as letters or messages pour in, a lot of them arrive at the same time from many different places. When he died, letters of sympathy poured in to his family from all over the world.
verb If someone pouts, they push out their lips and look discontented and sulky. It's no use poutingI said no TV and I mean it!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pout You can take that pout off your face right now!

form.definition: noun Poverty is the state of having very little money or resources. She was brought up in desperate poverty. How can we break the cycle of poverty and deprivation?
noun Powder is a substance that is made up of very small particles. ...talcum powder. ...face powder.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb powder Powder the biscuits with fine sugar.adjective powdered ...powdered milk.adjective powdery The snow was crisp and powdery.

form.definition: noun Power is the ability to control or dominate people or events. She rose to a position of considerable power in the organisation. Some people seek power for its own sake rather than for what they hope to achieve.

Your physical or mental power is your strength or ability. This word is sometimes used in the plural. You'll need a lot of power to lift that big rock. The task was beyond my power. Her powers of reasoning are impressive. As we grow older, our powers begin to fade.

noun If you have the power to do something, you have the authority to do it. The council has the power to shut down the shop if health regulations are being broken. She exceeded her powers in trying to have him fired.
noun A power is a strong or influential person or country. The USA is a world power. The regional managers are the real powers in the corporation.
noun Power is energy that is used to operate equipment or machinery. The train runs on steam power.
noun Power can also refer to electricity. I'll have to turn off the power to install the light fitting. We had a power cut last night.
adjective A power tool is operated by electricity. ...a power screwdriver. ...power steering.
noun In mathematics, a power of a number is that number multiplied by itself a certain number of times. 16 is the fourth power of 2.
A power point is an outlet for[qr

dictionary.entry: electricity. You push the pins on an electric plug into the holes of a power point so that you can operate an electrical device. The electrician asked me where I wanted the power points. ... WORD FAMILY verb power The boat is powered by a simple motor. He powered his way through the water.adjective powerful This is a powerful drug. Don't cross hershe's a powerful woman.

form.definition: noun A P-plate is a small square sign with the letter P in red on a white background. Newly qualified drivers must display these signs on the front and back of their cars for a certain period after they pass the driving test.
adjective If something is practical, it is sensible and likely to work well. Her ideas are always very practical.
adjective If someone is practical, they are realistic and deal well with real-life situations. Li-Ling is much more practical than her husbandhe's a dreamer.
adjective If something is practical, it is useful, but not necessarily attractive. A set of saucepans is a very practical wedding present for a young couple.
adjective A practical lesson or examination involves actually doing an experiment or making something, not just reading and writing about a subject.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb See practically.

form.definition: adverb Practically means 'almost'. We were practically home when the car ran out of petrol. I know practically nothing about the subject. At the time we were practically strangers.
adverb If you do something practically, you do it sensibly, bearing in mind the resources that are available. Speaking practically, can you give me an idea of what you need for the conference?
noun Practice is regular training in a particular activity or sport. I have a dreadful time getting the kids to do their piano practice. Practice makes perfect.

noun Practice is the way things are in reality, as opposed to the way they are said or meant to be. That idea sounds good in theorybut how does it work in practice? The timetable says it's a 20-minute trip, but in practice it's more like half an hour.

noun In rather formal language, a practice is something that you do regularly. It is my practice to get up at six and take a walk for half an hour. You may find it useful to adopt the practice of reviewing your work for a few minutes each day.
adjective Practice is the way that has become established for something to be done. The practice in this office is for the junior staff to take turns in collecting the mail.
noun A doctor's or lawyer's practice is their business. Dr Smith has moved her practice to High Street.

put into practice If you put something into practice, you actually do it, instead of just planning it. Last week Ali was able to put his pet theories about running a meeting into practiceand it was a disaster.

verb If you practise something such as a musical instrument or sport, you train regularly. Jan practises the piano every day for two hours. You can't expect to improve unless you keep practising. I practised my speech on my family the day before.
verb If you practise a habit or custom, you do it regularly. These traditions were still practised by the older members of the tribe. I'm nominally a Catholic, but I haven't practised for years.
verb If you practise a profession, such as medicine or law, you work in that profession. Many professionals with overseas qualifications find it difficult to practise in Australia.
form.note: ... NOTE that in Australian English, the noun is always spelt with a 'c' and the verb is always spelt with an 's'.

form.definition: verb If you praise someone or something, you say how impressed you are by them. Joshua was thrilled when the swimming coach praised him for all his hard work. The visitors all duly praised the new furnishings.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun praise Kids respond much better to praise and encouragement than to criticism.

form.definition: noun A pram is a wheeled carriage for a baby. The baby can lie down and sleep in it as it is pushed along.
form.note: ... COMPARE this with stroller.

form.definition: verb If someone prances or prances around, they move in an exaggerated way, often because they are showing off to other people. Just look at Donna prancing around over there in her tight jeans.
noun A prank is a trick or something silly that children do. They played a prank on the teacher by hiding his book. I don't think you need to worryit was just a harmless prank.
verb If someone prattles, they talk on and on in a rather silly way about unimportant things. For heaven's sake, stop prattling, and get on with your work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prattle His endless prattle can get very irritating after a while.[xp\start\prawn

form.definition: noun A prawn is a type of shellfish.

come the raw prawn In informal language, if you say that someone comes the raw prawn with you, you mean they try to fool or deceive you. Don't come the raw prawn with meI saw you with Geoff in the restaurant last night.
verb If you pray, you talk to the god that you believe in, often to ask for help or to be forgiven for something that you have done wrong.
verb If you say that you pray that something happens, you mean you really want it to happen because you feel very strongly about it. I pray that he gets well soon.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prayer He solemnly recited the prayer.

form.definition: verb Ministers preach when they give a sermon in church.
If someone preaches at you, they tell you how you should behave, even though they don't really understand your situation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun preacher Her father was a lay preacher.noun preacher

form.definition: adjective If something is precarious, there is a strong possibility that something will go wrong with it. Move that plate away from the edge of the tableit looks a bit precarious. My position at work is quite precarious since the change in managementI could be retrenched any day. ... WORD FAMILY adverb precariously He balanced precariously on the window ledge.

noun A precaution is any action that is done in order to prevent something unpleasant from happening. We've burned firebreaks right around the main homestead as a precaution against bushfire. The insurance will be invalid if you don't take reasonable precautions to protect your property.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective precautionary ...precautionary measures.

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say that something precedes something else, you mean it happens before it. The dinner will be preceded by a cocktail reception. If your application precedes July 1, it will be dealt with under the old rules.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective preceding His name is given in full in the preceding paragraph.

form.definition: noun A precedent is a decision or action that will be used as a guide for future decisions. The judge's ruling set an important precedent for similar claims. You may do it this time, but please don't take this as a precedent.

adjective If something is precious, it is very important to you. You would be very upset to lose it. This book is precious to me because it belonged to my mother. I hate spending my precious free time doing the chores.
adjective If something is precious, it is worth a lot of money. Gold is a precious metal. The necklace was set with precious stones. Several precious art works were destroyed in the fire.
noun A precipice is a very steep drop over a cliff or off a mountain. The car nearly drove over the precipice because the end of the road wasn't clearly marked.

dictionary.entry: precis`prEIsi:precis\minion0\/\times0\presiz\minion0\/)\minion0\nounA precis is a short summary of a longer piece of writing. All the main points are mentioned, and the overall sense is kept, but the small details are left out.

form.definition: adjective If something is precise, it is specific and detailed. It is not vague. The witness was able to give a precise description of the robber. I'll arrive in the late afternoonI'm afraid I can't be more precise than that.
adjective A precise time or amount is exactly that time or amount. This is the precise spot where the accident happened. I can't give you a precise time, but it'll be between ten and twelve.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb precisely We left at precisely eight o'clock. It's precisely two metres long.noun precision

form.definition: adjective If a child is precocious, they are much more mature and sophisticated, and sometimes also talented, than most children of their age. Anne-Marie was a precocious childshe was reading Dickens before she was ten. He showed a precocious gift for music. I'd like to avoid Anthea and her precocious brats.
noun Your predecessor in a job is the person who had the job or position before you did.
noun A predicament is a difficult situation that you find yourself in. Jerome is in love with his best friend's girlfriendit's an awkward predicament.

verb If you predict something, you say that you think or are sure that it will happen. The weather forecast predicted rain for tomorrow. I predicted that their marriage wouldn't last, and I was right. He claims to be able to predict the future from the stars.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prediction

form.definition: adjective If something is predictable, it is exactly what you would expect. It is not at all surprising. Arthur reacted with predictable hostility. I regretted turning my back on my safe and predictable existence. Don't be so predictabletry something new!
adjective If something is predominant, it forms the larger part of a whole. There is more of it than of anything else. The predominant colours were red and brown.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb predominantly Our customers are predominantly from the local area, but we do get some tourists.verb predominate People under twenty tend to predominate at these parties.

form.definition: verb When birds preen their feathers, they clean them with their beak.

preen yourself If you preen yourself, you show that you are very pleased with your appearance or your achievements. She spends hours preening herself in front of the mirror. Jason really preened himself when the chairman singled him out for praise.
noun A preface is a short introduction at the beginning of a book. It is usually written by someone famous and recommends people to read the book.

verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone prefaces what they say or write with certain remarks, you mean they make these remarks at the beginning, before the rest of what they say or write. I must preface my speech with an apology for my late arrival. The statistical appendix is prefaced with a note about how the data was analysed.
noun In a school, a prefect is a senior student with special duties and responsibilities.

verb If you prefer something, you like it more than another thing. Jane's nice, but I prefer her sister. I prefer dogs to cats. Would you prefer rice or noodles? I'd prefer to wait, if you don't mind. We can go by train if you prefer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective preferable It's preferable to apply as soon as possible.noun preference My preference would be to go on Tuesday, but I could make Monday too.

form.definition: noun A prefix is a part at the beginning of a word which affects its meaning. For example, the negative prefix un- changes happy into unhappy.
adjective If a woman is pregnant, she is going to have a baby. When I was pregnant with Josh, I was sick for the whole nine months.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pregnancy (pregnancies) It was a difficult pregnancy, but it was worth it.

form.definition: noun Prejudice is a strong belief or opinion that someone has for no valid reason. Luis has a prejudice against women who work and he just won't listen to anyone else's opinion.
verb If you prejudice something, you put it in danger. I don't want to prejudice my chances of promotion by complaining. Getting involved with drugs will prejudice your entire future.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective prejudiced My parents were racially prejudiced.

form.definition: adjective Preliminary actions take place before the main activities in a sequence of events. Preliminary discussions on the new pay structure will be held next week. The chair made a few preliminary remarks before the first delegate spoke.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun preliminary (preliminaries) Cleaning the woodwork is an essential preliminary to painting it.

form.definition: noun A prelude is a piece of music that is played as an introduction to a performance.

noun A prelude to something is an event or happening that occurs just before it and leads up to it. Her family left Europe during the prelude to the Second World War. He cleared his throat as a prelude to speaking.

adjective If something is premature, it is too soon. It happens before it ought to or before it usually does. His announcement was a bit prematurehe didn't get the job after all. Exposure to the sun causes premature ageing of the skin.
adjective If a baby is premature, it is born less than nine months after it was conceived. Jessica was nearly two months premature, but she pulled through.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb prematurely

form.definition: noun In Australia, a premier is the leader of a state government. Compare this with prime minister.
adjective If something is described as premier, it is of top quality or the best of its kind. All our products are made from premier ingredients. She was one of the premier film actors of her day.
noun The premiere of a film or play is its first public performance.
noun A premise is a statement that you take as true and on which you base further discussion. Working from the premise that change is inevitable, we must try to get the changes we want.

premises Premises are a set of rooms or buildings used for a particular purpose, for example an office, a hotel or a factory. OFFICE PREMISES FOR SALE OR LEASE The troublemaker was escorted off the premises. No tools or materials may be taken away from the premises without permission.
noun A premium is the sum of money that you pay in return for insurance. Premiums have risen this year because of the increase in theft and vandalism.
noun A premium is a bonus or gift that is offered in order to get you to buy something. They enclosed a set of stickers as a premium in the first issue.

adjective If something is described as premium, it is of high quality and often more expensive than other things of the same kind. Enjoy our premium blended teas. We use only premium cuts of meat in our recipes.
at a premium If something is at a premium, it is hard to obtain. There is not much of it compared with the number of people who want it. Houses with water views are at a premium.
noun If you have a premonition, you get a strong feeling about something, usually something bad, that's going to happen. Val didn't get on the plane because she had a premonition that it would crash.

adjective If you are preoccupied with something, you think about it so much that it's hard to concentrate on anything else. This week I'm preoccupied with arrangements for the trip. You look very preoccupiedis anything the matter? Helen's got very boringshe's totally preoccupied with her children.
verb If you prepare for something, you get ready for it. We're busy preparing for my mother's visit.
verb If you prepare something, you get it ready. Richard had prepared a speech just in case he won. How do you prepare asparagus?
verb If you prepare someone for something, you make them ready to cope with it. Our maths teacher prepared us well for our exams. Nothing in his previous experience had prepared him for this moment.
verb If you prepare to do something, you are just about to do it. Emil prepared to leave the room when Stella came in, but she asked him to stay.
prepared If you are prepared to do something, you are willing to do it. You can turn up without an appointment if you're prepared to wait. I'm not prepared to be treated like this!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun preparation There are a lot of preparations to be made before the conference.

form.definition: noun In grammar, a preposition is a word used before a noun phrase to show a relationship such as where something is or when it happens.
adjective If something is preposterous, it is completely absurd and ridiculous. It's quite preposterous to suggest it can be done in three weeks. He turned up in a preposterous purple suit.
verb If a doctor prescribes a medicine, they advise you to take it and they write out a prescription for it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See prescription.

form.definition: noun A prescription is a written instruction from a doctor for a pharmacist to dispense a medicine to a patient. Many drugs are available only on prescription.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is script.

dictionary.entry:
present`prEz@nt <for senses 1 to 5>; for senses 6 and pr@`zEnt
noun The present is the time that is happening now. I try to live in the presentthere's no point regretting the past or dreaming about the future.
In grammar, the present is the tense you use to say what usually happens (the or what is happening now (the .
simplepresentpresentcontinuous
adjective If something is described as present, it exists now. Our present policy is not to accept cheques. The present manager will retire next year.
adjective If you are present somewhere, you are there. About twelve people were present at the meeting.
... THE OPPOSITE of this is absent.
noun A present is a gift. You may give it to someone for a special occasion such as their birthday or Christmas.
verb If you present something to someone or present them with it, you give it to them, usually at a formal ceremony. When I left that job they presented me with a beautiful watch. He was presented with the award for the most promising newcomer.
If you present something such as a report, you make people aware of it, often by giving a sort of lecture in public. The researchers presented their findings at a big medical conference.
at present At present means 'now'. I'm rather busy at presentcould you come back later? I am at present completing an MA in Communication and am keen to find employment in this field.
... WORD FAMILY adverb See presently. noun presentation Joel's was the best presentation at the seminar.noun presence Mario's presence made the others uneasythey wished he wasn't there.

form.definition: adjective If someone is presentable, they are tidy and dressed appropriately for the occasion. 'Do I look presentable?' 'No, go and get changed. You'll need to wear a tieit's pretty formal.'
adverb If something will happen presently, it will happen soon. I'll be with you presentlydo take a seat.
adverb If something is happening presently, it is happening now. I'm presently working for my brother, but I'd like to have my own business one day.

verb In rather formal language, if you say that you preserve something, you mean you keep it carefully or maintain it. You do not lose it or discard it. His mother had preserved all his letters in a box. I struggled to preserve my dignity.

verb If you preserve something, you take special measures to keep it in good condition. This may involve treating it with chemical substances or keeping it in a particular environment. The display contains animal foetuses preserved in jars. The drawings are carefully preserved in conditions of controlled temperature and humidity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun preservation noun preservative Packaged foods often contain preservatives and colourings.

form.definition: noun The president of a country that is a republic is the person who holds the highest official position.
noun The president of a company is the head of the company.
noun The president of an organisation such as a sports club or a Parents and Citizens Association is the leader elected by the members.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun presidency adjective presidential ...a presidential candidate. ...a presidential election.

form.definition: verb If you press something, you push it to act on it in some way. He pressed the accelerator and the car sped away. Does it hurt when I press on your stomach here?
verb If you press something against something else, you push it against it. She pressed herself against the wall and waited till the crowd had passed.
verb If you press something, you squeeze it. She pressed his hand gently. He presses wild flowers as a hobby.
verb If you press clothes, you iron them. These trousers need pressingthey're all creased.
verb If someone presses you to do something, they try hard to get you to do it.
noun The press is the media, especially newspapers. He was hounded by the press.
noun A press is a machine which prints words and pictures onto paper to make books, magazines and newspapers.
press conference When someone holds a press conference, they have a meeting with journalists in order to make an announcement or to answer questions.
noun Press-up is another word for push-up.
noun Pressure is the force that physical objects exert on the things they are in contact with. Have you checked the air pressure in your tyres?
noun Pressure is the force you use to move something or to open something.
noun Pressure is persuasion that someone uses to try to get you to do something. Luigi put pressure on his mother to lend him her new car.
noun Pressure is a feeling of stress that you can get if you have too much to do. I'm really feeling the pressure at work.
pressure group A pressure group is an organisation of people who try to persuade politicians to make changes in a particular area of policy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pressure He tried to pressure me into changing my mind.

form.definition: noun Prestige is a high reputation with other people.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective prestigious Sheila has moved into a prestigious position in the organisation.

form.definition: verb If you presume that something is the case, you think it's so because of other things you know, even though you don't know for sure about this. I haven't heard from Jim but I presume he'll be at the party.

verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone presumes to do something, you mean that they do it although they have no right or justification. How dare you presume to tell me what to do? ... WORD FAMILY noun presumption
verb If you pretend that something is the case, you try to make other people believe that it's true, even though it isn't really. I pretended to be pleased to see her.
verb If you pretend to do something, you act as though you are doing it but you don't really do it. She pretended to ring her mother but she really dialled her own number.

verb If you pretend that something is the case, you think for a while about how things would be if it was true, even though you know that it isn't really. When I was a little girl, I used to pretend that I was a princess. OK, pretend that you've just arrived at the airportwhat's the first thing you'd do?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pretence It was hard to keep up the pretence that I'd never seen him before.

dictionary.entry:
pretty`prIti:prettierprettiest 1a adjective If someone is pretty, they are attractive. You use this word mainly to talk about girls and young children. It is not as strong in its meaning
adjective If something is pretty, it is attractive in a rather conventional way. The box was decorated with a pretty bow. The dresses are too pretty for my taste.
adverb In informal language, you can use pretty to mean 'fairly' or 'quite'. I've been getting pretty good marks. It seems pretty funny when I look back. The money disappears pretty quickly.
pretty well In informal language, pretty well is used to mean 'almost' or 'nearly'. She told me pretty well everything. We've pretty well finished now.
... WORD FAMILY noun prettiness

form.definition: adjective In rather formal language, if you say that something is prevalent, you mean that it is widespread or common. Violence has become increasingly prevalent in society.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prevalence

form.definition: verb If someone prevaricates, they are vague and try to avoid saying something because they think that it will cause someone to be upset. Come on, stop prevaricating and tell me what happened.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prevarication

form.definition: verb If you prevent someone from doing something or prevent something from happening, you make sure that they don't do it or it doesn't happen. He's a grown boyyou can't really prevent him from seeing his friends. I wore an apron to prevent my clothes from getting dirty. Clean the cut thoroughly to prevent infection.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prevention Prevention is better than cure.

form.definition: noun A preview is a performance of something such as a movie or play which takes place before the official opening.

adjective If something is described as previous, it happened before something else of the same kind. Let me go back to your previous question. She has two children from a previous marriage and a baby with Jake.
adjective The previous day or year is the one immediately before the one you're talking about. He came on Wednesday but he should have come the previous day.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb previously Sonya stayed behind, as I'd previously asked her to.

form.definition: noun Prey is an animal hunted by another animal or by a human for food. The dingo never lost sight of its prey.

prey on someone's mind If something is preying on someone's mind, they are very worried about it and find it hard to stop thinking about it. Her warning preyed on my mind. It's been preying on my mind that I was so mean to Tariq.

noun The price of something is the amount of money it costs. The prices are marked on each item. The quality is good, but the prices are rather high. Pensioners are admitted for half price. I asked the price of the vase I liked.

noun The price that you have to pay for something desirable or worthwhile is the unpleasant aspect that goes with it. If you want to be a top athlete, you have to pay the pricehard training, early mornings, and not much social life.

at any price If you say that you want something at any price, you mean you are determined to have it, and you don't care what you have to sacrifice to obtain it. She was determined to go to college at any price, even if it meant leaving all her friends.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb price Their stock is very reasonably priced.adjective See priceless.

form.definition: adjective If something is priceless, it is extremely valuable and impossible to replace. Many priceless antiques were destroyed in the blaze.
adjective A priceless talent or skill is one that it is wonderful to have. His musical ability is a priceless gift.
adjective If you describe someone as priceless, you mean that you find them very amusing or unique. Look at John over therehe's priceless, isn't he?
adjective If something is pricey, it is expensive. Tania didn't buy the dress because it was a bit too priceyshe said she'd wait till the January sales.
verb If you prick something, you jab it with something sharp. Use a thimble so you don't prick your finger with the needle. Prick the sausages with a fork before you cook them.
prick up your ears If you prick up your ears, you suddenly begin to listen carefully to something. I pricked up my ears when I heard my name mentioned.
noun Pride is a feeling of pleasure about something that you've achieved. What are my feelings? Well, pride mainlyI'm just so thrilled to represent my country at the Olympics.
noun Pride is also your sense of dignity and self-respect. She struggled on because her pride wouldn't allow her to ask for help.
noun Pride can also be an opinion of yourself which is too high. It's sheer pride that's preventing him from admitting he was wrong. Pride goes before a fall.
pride yourself If you pride yourself on a certain skill, you are pleased and confident about it. He prides himself on his ability at squash. I pride myself that I'm an excellent judge of character.

take pride in If you take pride in something, it is a source of satisfaction to you. Sofia takes great pride in her sonhe's done so well at school. I take pride in being an Australian. I wish Omar would take more pride in his workhe could do so well.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See proud.

form.definition: noun A priest is a minister of religion, especially in the Catholic church.
noun A prig is someone who believes that they are morally better than other people and has no sense of humour. I can't stand Bobhe's a boring prig.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective priggish

form.definition: adjective If someone is prim, they are very correct and proper in their behaviour and often seem to be rather old-fashioned. Don't swear in front of Ellenshe's very prim.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb primly

form.definition: adjective Primary means 'main' or 'most important'. Your health is our primary concerneverything else can wait. Their primary need is for warm clothing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb primarily

form.definition: noun A primary school is a school with classes from kindergarten through to grade 6 or 7. It is the first stage of compulsory education for children. Compare this with high school.
adjective If something is described as prime, it is of very high quality. The racehorse was in prime condition, and was expected to win easily. We use only prime cuts of lean steak.
adjective A prime example of something is a very good or typical example of it. This accident is a prime example of your carelessness.

in the prime of life If someone is in the prime of life, they are at the best or most productive stage of their life. Now he's in the prime of life his poetry is better than ever. It was a tragedy that she died in the prime of life, at the age of only 35.
A prime minister in Australia is the leader of the federal government in Canberra.
form.note: ... COMPARE this with premier.

form.definition: A prime number is a number that has no factors except itself. It cannot be divided by any other numbers a whole number of times without a remainder.
adjective If something is primitive, it belongs to an early stage of development. Primitive metal armour has been excavated from the site.
adjective If something is primitive, it is very simple and basic. The hotel is a bit primitive but at least it's clean.
noun A prince is a male member of a royal family, a son or brother of a king or queen.
noun A prince is also the husband of a reigning queen.
noun A princess is a female member of a royal family, a daughter or sister of a king or queen.
noun A princess is also a woman who has married a prince.
adjective In rather formal language, principal means 'main'. The appointment that was the principal reason for my trip was cancelled.
noun The principal of a school or college is the person who is in charge of it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb principally

form.definition: noun A principle is a general rule or standard of behaviour by which you act. Alby is a man of high principle. She has no principlesshe's a cheat and a liar. I acted on the principle that it was better to get the unpleasantness over.

in principle If something is true in principle, it is broadly or theoretically true, but perhaps not in detail or in practice. My boss has agreed in principle to give me time off, but we haven't agreed the dates yet.
verb When something such as a book, magazine or newspaper is printed, many copies of it are made on a machine called a printing press.
verb If you print a document that you have written on a computer, you send a copy of the data electronically to a machine called a printer and it comes out on paper.
verb If you print when you write something by hand, you write each letter separately instead of joining them together. Please print your name and address in capital letters.
noun Print is the words on the pages of a book, magazine or newspaper. She was thrilled to see her name in print when they published her letter.
noun A print is a picture of which many copies have been made by a process of reproduction. Her office was decorated with 19th-century prints.
noun A print is one of the photographs from a film which has been developed. How many prints of each photo do you want?
in print If a book is in print, it is still being sold by the publisher and you can buy or order it from a bookshop.
out of print If a book is out of print, it is no longer being sold by the publisher and you cannot get it from a bookshop that sells only new books.
noun A printer is an electronic machine that you use to make a copy on paper of a document that you have written on a computer.
noun A printer is a person or a company that produces many copies of things such as books, newspapers or advertising leaflets.
adjective In rather formal language, prior means 'previous' or 'before now'. No prior experience is necessary for the job. My prior meeting with him had shown me what to expect.

adjective A prior meeting or appointment is one which was arranged earlier, and which will prevent you from attending something else. I'd like to come to the lunch tomorrow, but I'm afraid I have a prior engagement.
prior to If something happens prior to something else, it happens before it. She was very sick just prior to her weddingfortunately she recovered in time.

noun If something is a priority, it must be done or dealt with as soon as possible. It must be done before other things that are less important or urgent. My priority today is to get the agenda out in time for the meeting.
verb If you prise something open, you manage to get it open although it is quite firmly stuck. Often you have to use something as a lever to open it.
noun A prism is a transparent, glass object with three triangular sides. It separates light into the colours of the rainbow.

noun A prison is a place where criminals serve a sentence of imprisonment after they have been convicted of a crime. He's spent most of his adult life in prison. She was sent to prison for six months.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is jail or gaol. ... WORD FAMILY verb imprison She was imprisoned for six months.noun prisoner

form.definition: adjective If something is private, it belongs to someone and is for their use only. It is not public. There is no right of way hereyou're trespassing on private property.

adjective If something is private, it is confidential. It is not appropriate for everyone to know about it. She's got no business asking about private family matters. Could I have a private talk with you? The letter was marked 'private'.

adjective Your private life is all the aspects of your life that have nothing to do with your work. The boss shouldn't interfere in Joe's private life. People are always eager to gossip about the private lives of celebrities.

adjective If something is private, it is owned and operated by a commercial organisation. It is not run by the government. Our girls go to a small private school. My sister is a doctor working in private practice.
private enterprise Private enterprise is the system of business and commercial activity which is operated by independent companies rather than by the government.
private parts Your private parts are your genitals.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun privacy I didn't want to intrude on her privacy.adverb privately May I speak to you privately for a moment?

form.definition: noun A privilege is a special right or advantage that one person or group has and others do not. This membership card entitles you to special privileges, such as free parking and a discount at our restaurant.
noun A privilege is an honour. It's a great privilege to meet a writer whose books I admire so much.
noun A prize is something that you are awarded because you do well in an exam, competition or game. Li Ling won a beautiful book as first prize in the history essay competition.
noun A prize is money or something such as a car that you win in a lottery or other game of chance.
verb If you prize something, you value it very highly. You treasure it. I really prize my day off workit's a chance to relax and unwind.
adjective If something is described as being prize, it is of very good quality. Don't touch Mum's prize orchids or she'll kill you!
adjective If something is probable, it is likely to be happen or be true. The probable time of arrival is early in the morning, but it depends on the weather.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb probably We'll probably see her on the weekend.

form.definition: verb If you probe something, you push or prod something into it in order to test it or find out what the matter is. Jim winced as the dentist probed the cavity.
verb If you probe something, you try to find out the facts about it. You investigate it. POLICE PROBE SCHOOL DRUG SCANDAL ... WORD FAMILY verb probe He shrieked as the dentist probed his tooth.
noun A problem is a difficult situation that needs attention. They agreed to see a counsellor about their marriage problems. I'm sorry I'm lateI had a problem with the car.
noun In maths, a problem is a question to be solved by logical analysis.
no problem In informal language, you can say no problem to show that you are willing to do something. 'Can you help me with the washing up?' 'No problem.' 'Thanks a lot for the lift.' 'No problem.'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective problematic

form.definition: noun A procedure is a certain way of doing something. I don't know how to apply for the moneywhat's the correct procedure?

dictionary.entry:
proceedpr@`si:d <for senses 1 to 3>; for sense 4`pr@Usi:dz
verb If an activity proceeds, it continues without stopping. The meeting usually proceeds until all the items have been discussed.
verb If you proceed somewhere, you go straight there after doing something else. Take a ticket and proceed to your seat.
verb If you proceed to do something, you immediately go on to do it. She said she believed in minding her own business and then proceeded to tell me exactly what I should do.
proceeds The proceeds of a commercial transaction are the amount of money that is made from it. He bought a new car with the proceeds of the sale of his old truck.
... WORD FAMILY noun procession The procession of mourners moved slowly towards the cemetery.

form.definition: noun A process is a series of actions which bring about a change. The mechanic identified the problem by a process of eliminating possible causes. The injuries will heal, but it will be a long process. Growing up can be a painful process.
verb If you process something, you treat it in a particular way in order to get a result. This cheese has been processed to reduce its fat content. Your application is still being processed.
3 in the process of If you are in the process of doing something, you are in the middle of doing it. You are currently involved with it. We are in the process of selling our house.
verb If you prod someone or something, you poke them with something such as your finger or a stick. Stop prodding me in the ribs! I prodded the cockroach cautiously, but it was dead.
verb If you prod someone to do something, you try to make them do it. You remind them or urge them to do it. Michael is so lazy that I have to prod him to get up every morning.
noun A prodigy is someone, usually a child, who is outstandingly gifted in a particular area. Ramon's a real prodigyhe can play the piano like an expert and he's only eight.

dictionary.entry:
producepr@`dju:s for the verb>; <for the noun>,`prOdZu:s
verb To produce something means to create it, grow it, or make it. Australia produced over 14 million tonnes of wheat a year.
verb To produce something means to cause it or make it happen. The recession produced high unemployment. The mention of her name produced an extraordinary effect on him.
verb In rather formal language, if you produce something, you bring it out of somewhere in order to show it to someone. She produced a torn ticket from her pocket.
verb If someone produces a play or movie, they organise and manage the business aspect.
noun Produce is food that is grown to be sold.
... WORD FAMILY noun producer Chan-Woo wants to be a film producer.noun production noun See product.

form.definition: noun A product is something that is made to be sold. There's a great new oven-cleaning product on the market.
noun The product of an action is its result or outcome. This book is the product of hours of hard work.
noun In maths, the product is the number you get when you multiply two other numbers together.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun production

form.definition: adjective If something or someone is productive, they make or grow a large amount of something. The old cheese factory can no longer compete with more productive, modern factories.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun productivity Productivity has improved since we installed the new equipment.

form.definition: noun A profession is a job that requires special knowledge and training. She is a teacher by profession. He's a member of the legal professionhe's a solicitor.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective professional adverb professionally

form.definition: noun A professor is the most senior kind of teacher in a university. ...Professor Carlos La Torre.

adjective If someone is proficient, they are capable or skilled. John became quite proficient in Indonesian after living in Denpasar for six months. She's highly proficient at getting her own way. We need a fully proficient chef.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun proficiency

form.definition: noun Your profile is a side view of your face. The photographer asked Jean to face the camera, then turn her left profile.

noun A profile of someone published in a newspaper or magazine is an article about them, usually based on an interview. The journalist wrote a series of profiles of sports heroes for the weekend magazine.
keep a low profile If you keep a low profile, you try not to draw attention to yourself. Tehani is shy so she keeps a low profile at parties.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb profile

form.definition: noun In business, a profit is the difference between what something costs and how much it is sold for. He made a large profit when he sold his house. After years of losses, the company is heading back into profit.
noun In rather formal language, profit is benefit or advantage. There's no profit in losing your temperit only makes things worse.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb profit I was able to profit from Ben's experience and avoid the same mistake.adjective profitable The farm is barely profitable these days.

form.definition: adjective If something is profound, it is very intense in emotion. I felt a profound sadness to be leaving. The movie isn't very profound, but it's good entertainment.
noun A program for a computer is a set of instructions which it uses in order to do certain things.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun programmer Minh is a computer programmer.

form.definition: noun A programme is a plan to do something. It involves several stages and takes place over quite a long period of time. The programme of renovations on the building has fallen behind schedule. I signed up for an adult education programme. You need to work out an exercise programme you can stick to.
noun A programme is a particular show on the TV or radio. The children were arguing about which TV programme to watch.
noun At a play or concert, a programme is a leaflet which gives details of the performance.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING that's commonly used, especially for sense 3, is program.

dictionary.entry:
progress`pr@UgrEs <for the noun>; <for the verb>,pr@`grEs
noun Progress is improvement or an advance towards a better state. Joan is making good progress in her studies.
noun In rather formal language, the progress of something is the way it is developing or working out. We followed the progress of the discussions with interest.
noun In rather formal language, the progress of something is its movement forwards. The navy monitored the progress of the enemy ships using high-powered radar equipment. Little can be done to stop the progress of the cancer.
verb If something progresses, it continues, develops or becomes more advanced. As time progressed we saw less and less of each other. The cancer has progressed to other parts of his body. The students are progressing satisfactorily in their studies.

form.definition: adjective If someone is progressive, they are in favour of social change.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is conservative.

form.definition: adjective If something is progressive, it happens more and more as time goes on. We must take action to halt the progressive decline in standards.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb progressively The situation became progressively worse.

form.definition: verb To prohibit something is to forbid it by a law or rule. Smoking is prohibited in these offices.

dictionary.entry:
project`pr@UdZEkt, `prO-/ for the noun>; <for the pr@`dZEkt
noun A project is an activity that has to be carefully planned. His latest project is to build a boat using Australian timber. Gloria was put in charge of the project to review our marketing.
noun A project at a school or college is an assignment that involves researching different aspects of a topic. I handed in my history project two days late.
verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone projects something, you mean they throw it up high. The guns on the ground projected anti-aircraft missiles. You must project your voice so that the people at the back of the hall can hear you.
verb If someone projects a film, they show it on a screen.
verb In rather formal language, if you say that something projects, you mean that it sticks out. The headland projected into the bay. File off any projecting edges.
... WORD FAMILY noun projector We managed to borrow a projector and enjoyed watching our holiday slides.

form.definition: noun A prologue is a speech or text at the beginning of a play or a book. It serves as an introduction to it.

verb If you prolong something, you make it last longer. Don't prolong the suspensetell me if Maria got the job. We decided to prolong our stay by a couple of days. Must doctors try to prolong life in all circumstances?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective prolonged He died after a prolonged struggle with cancer.

form.definition: noun A promenade is a wide street, often beside the sea.
noun A promenade is a slow walk or stroll that you take in a town. We decided to go for a promenade before dinner.
adjective If someone is prominent, they are important or well known. She married a prominent local lawyer.
adjective If something is prominent, it is very noticeable. The posters were placed in prominent positions around the city. Ari is quite handsome, but his nose is a bit too prominent.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prominence adverb prominently

form.definition: verb If you promise to do something, you say that you will definitely do it. Do you promise to be home by nine? She promised that she wouldn't do it again. You won't regret it, I promise. They promise your money back if you're not satisfied.
noun A promise is a pledge or statement that you will definitely do something. I always keep my promises. He broke his promise not to tell anyone.

noun If someone or something shows promise, they show signs that they are likely to be successful in the future. Muoi shows great promise as a violinistshe's going to the conservatorium. Albert's approach to the problem seemed to show most promise.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective promising She's one of Australia's most promising young violinists.

form.definition: verb If you are promoted at work, you are given a more senior job with more money. Reweti has been with the company for only six months and he's already been promoted.

verb If a company promotes a product, they advertise it and try to get people to buy it. Their new range of sauces has been heavily promoted on television. She's travelling around the country promoting her new book.
verb In rather formal language, if you say that something promotes some action, you mean that it helps it to happen. This antiseptic ointment promotes rapid healing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun promotion He got a promotion after only six months.adjective promotional ...a promotional video. ...promotional literature.

form.definition: adjective If something is prompt, it happens very soon after the event that makes it necessary. Thank you for your prompt reply to my letter. Prompt payment appreciated: 5% discount for settlement in full within 14 days. Only her prompt action saved his life.

verb If something prompts you to do something, it is the reason why you do it. A rattling sound in the gearbox prompted me to take the car to a service station. What prompted you to apply for this job?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb promptly

form.definition: adjective If you are prone to something, you often suffer from it. Patients with damaged immune systems are very prone to infections. Large parts of Australia are prone to drought.

adjective If you are prone to do something, you often do it. You have a tendency to do it. Mirek is prone to talk about himself rather too much. I'm prone to put on weight if I don't watch myself carefully.
adjective If you lie prone, you lie on your front.[qr

dictionary.entry:
prongprON
noun A prong is one of the sharp points on something such as a fork.

form.definition: noun In grammar, a pronoun is a word which is used in place of a noun, usually one that has already been mentioned.
verb If you pronounce a word, you say it in a certain way. How do you pronounce your surname? She pronounced the unfamiliar word carefully.

verb In formal language, if you say that someone pronounces something, you mean they declare it officially. The judge is ready to pronounce sentence. The doctor pronounced him dead. At the end of the wedding ceremony the celebrant pronounces the couple man and wife.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pronouncement We're waiting for a pronouncement about the future of the company.noun pronunciation I checked the pronunciation of the word in a dictionary.

form.definition: adjective If something is pronounced, it is fairly great and obvious. He walks with a pronounced limp. There has been a pronounced decline in output this quarter.
noun Proof is definite evidence that something is true. You say she cheated, but have you got proof? I sent in the remains of my passport as proof that it really had been through the washing machine.

adjective In formal language, if you say that something is proof against something, you mean it cannot be affected by it. This word is used mainly in compounds such as waterproof, rainproof and stainproof, which are not formal. Bars on doors and windows made the house proof against robbery.
noun A proof is a first copy of something printed, which is checked to make sure there are no mistakes before the rest of the copies are printed. The printer sent us a proof of the invitation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb prove

form.definition: verb If you prop something somewhere, you put it in a position where it is supported by something behind it. I propped the ladder against the wall. She reclined on the lounge, propped up by cushions.
noun Propaganda is information that is given in order to make people hold a certain point of view. It's hard to sift the party propaganda from the facts in this election campaign.
verb If a force propels something, it acts on it and causes it to move. The plane is propelled by jet engines. He seized my arm and propelled me towards the door.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun propellor Watch out for the boat propellor!

form.definition: adjective If something is described as proper, it is right or correct. It is the way it is supposed to be. I made it 357what's the proper answer? Can you show me the proper way to use the photocopier? You have to put each tool in the proper compartment, or they won't fit.

adjective If something is described as proper, it is a good example of the thing. It isn't just something that you make do with. I did casual work in a bar while I looked for a proper job. You need a proper meal before you set out. I felt much better after a proper night's sleep.

proper noun In grammar, a proper noun is the name of a person, place or organisation. In English, proper nouns are written with a capital letter at the beginning of each word, for example Sarah Jones, Tennant Creek, Gamblers Anonymous.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb properly I couldn't get the document to print out properly.

form.definition: noun Your property is the things that belong to you. Be sure that you take all your property with you when you leave the train. I hate it when people interfere with my property.
noun Property is buildings and land that people own as an investment. She owns over a million dollars in shares and property. We're looking for a property near the waterfront.
noun The proportion of one thing when compared with another is its relative size or number. What's the proportion of male to female students in the engineering faculty?
noun A proportion of something is a part of it when compared with the whole. Studying for my course takes a large proportion of my time each week.

in proportion If something is in proportion, it is a proper or appropriate size when compared with something else. Zelig's head is big, but it's in proportion with the rest of his body. Let's keep this problem in proportionit's not as bad as you think.
proportions In rather formal language, the proportions of something are its size. It is a building of vast proportions.

verb In rather formal language, if you say that someone proposes a certain plan or idea, you mean they suggest it. I propose that we all go out to dinner. Tina proposed waiting until the rain stopped. Eli proposed a different solution to the problem.

verb In rather formal language, if you say that you propose to do something, you mean that you intend to do it. What do you propose to do about the money you owe me? I don't propose to wait any longer.
verb If you propose to someone, you ask them to marry you.

propose a toast If you propose a toast to someone, you invite everyone at a gathering to join you in congratulating them and having a drink in their honour. Ladies and gentlemen, I propose a toast to the bride and groom.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun proposal noun proposition

dictionary.entry: proprietary limited company /\times,0\prpratri lmtd k... mpni/ noun A proprietary limited company is a company which is not listed on the stock exchange and has no more than fifty shareholders. The name of such a company is usually followed by the abbreviation Pty Ltd.

form.definition: noun The proprietor of a business is its owner or manager.

adverb If a salary for a part-time or temporary job is quoted pro rata, it means that it is the appropriate fraction of the full-time or annual salary. They want someone for three days a week at $500 a week pro rata, so you'd get $300 a week.
noun Prose is written language that is not poetry.
verb If someone is prosecuted for a crime, a court case is brought against them and there is a trial to decide whether or not they are guilty. TRESPASSERS WILL BE PROSECUTED
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prosecution She was called as a witness for the prosecution.

form.definition: noun A prospect is something that you expect to happen in the future. I hate the prospect of having to get up so early in the mornings. The company's in difficulty, and Ali faces the prospect of retrenchment.
noun A prospect is a chance or possibility of something happening. There is no prospect of finishing on schedule. What are the prospects for a fine day tomorrow?
verb If you prospect for something, you look around carefully to see if you can find it. I'll begin prospecting for a new unit once the weather gets warmer.
verb If you prospect, you look for gold. Old Bill's been prospecting in these hills for years.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective prospective I showed the car to several prospective buyers.

form.definition: noun A prospectus is a leaflet which gives you information that you need before deciding whether to do something. Have you seen the prospectus for continuing education courses at the university? Obtain a copy of our prospectus to see how you can become a shareholder.
verb If you prosper, you do well in life. You are fortunate and successful. How are your familycontinuing to prosper, I hope? The business is really prospering now that the recession is over.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prosperity He wished us good health and prosperity.adjective prosperous The once prosperous commercial centre is now largely deserted.

form.definition: noun A prostitute is someone who has sex in return for money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun prostitution

form.definition: verb If you protect someone or something, you try to prevent them from being damaged or injured. I put the papers in a bag to protect them from the rain. You should wear a hat to protect yourself against the sun. It's not possible to protect your children forever.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective See protective. noun protection

form.definition: adjective If something is described as protective, it is used to prevent something from being damaged. The wrapping material includes a waterproof protective layer.

adjective If someone is protective, they try very hard to look after the people they are fond of and prevent them from being hurt or upset. He's very protective of his colleagueshe'll always speak up in their favour. It can be a mistake to be too protective towards your children.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb protectively

form.definition: noun Protein is a substance found in some foods, such as milk, meat, cheese and eggs. Your body needs protein to be healthy.

verb If you protest about something, you object to it. You speak out publicly against it. The demonstrators were protesting against the war. They wanted to move me to a smaller office, but I protested.

verb If you protest that something is the case, you insist that it is true. It's no use protesting your innocenceI saw you take the money. She protested that she had never intended to cause so much trouble.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY They ignored our protests and went ahead.noun protester Some of the protesters were arrested for trespassing.

form.definition: noun Protestants are members of one of the many Christian denominations which have separated from the Catholic Church since the sixteenth century.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective Protestant

form.definition: noun Protocol is a set of rules about the correct way to behave on formal occasions. The protocol is that you introduce the younger person to the older. It's important to obey the protocol and get permission from your supervisor.

noun The prototype of something such as a vehicle or machine is an original example which is made as a test. It is then used as the model from which copies are made and sold. The prototype of this motor was developed by a firm of engineers.

adjective If something is protracted, it takes a long time. She left the meeting after a protracted argument. The protracted negotiations at last resulted in agreement. It seemed that we faced a protracted delay.

adjective If you are proud, you are pleased about something that you've achieved. I was proud to get such a good mark. I renovated the kitchen myselfI'm rather proud of it. Your son's done very wellyou must be proud of him.
adjective If you are proud, your dignity and self-respect are very important to you. You don't want to seem weak. Grandfather was too proud to let us help him as he grew frail.
adjective If you are proud, you think that you are better than other people. She's too proud to apologise for her mistake.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb proudly noun See pride.

form.definition: verb If you prove something, you show that it is true by giving evidence. You say that he's a liar, but can you prove it? The fingerprints proved that she had handled the vase.

verb If something proves to be the case, it becomes apparent that it is so. Moving in together soon proved to be a bad idea. To our surprise, he proved an excellent tennis player. Our new car has so far proved reliable.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun proof adjective proven He's a proven liar. He's a player of proven ability.

form.definition: verb If you provide something, you supply it. You make it available. Food will be provided, but bring your own drink. My employer can provide a reference. A nearby tree provided shelter when it began to rain.
provide for (a) If you provide for someone, you support them financially. Jorge and Carmen work long hours to provide for their children.
(b) If you provide for something, you allow for it in your planning. This pattern provides for seam allowances of 1 cm.
noun The provision of something is supplying it or making it available.
provisions Provisions are supplies of food and drink.

adjective If something is provisional, it is temporary. It is intended to be replaced by something else. If you pass your driving test, you get a provisional licence for a year, and an unrestricted licence when that expires. I made a provisional appointment for Monday, but he'll confirm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb provisionally I've provisionally booked you in for Monday.

form.definition: verb If something provokes a certain reaction, it causes it to happen. His joke provoked loud laughter. The decision has provoked widespread protest.
verb If someone provokes you, they deliberately say or do something that they know will make you angry. Jim only mentioned the election to provoke Silvio. Stop provoking your little sister.
