verb If an animal prowls, it moves quietly in search of prey. Be sure and lock the dooryou never know who may be prowling around outside. ... WORD FAMILY noun prowl The boss is on the prowl for latecomers.
noun A proxy is someone who is authorised to act instead of someone else, for example by voting on their behalf in an election.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective proxy ...a proxy vote.

form.definition: adjective If you are prudent, you are cautious and think carefully before acting. There is a lot of money to be made by prudent investors. It would be prudent to wait a bit longer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb prudently

form.definition: noun A prune is a dried plum.
verb If you prune a tree or a shrub, you cut back its branches. You trim it to make it look neater and grow better next season.

verb If someone pries, they try to find out about other people's affairs. They show great interest in matters which do not really concern them. I don't want to pry, but would it help to talk about it?
verb Pry is also another word for prise. Tom managed to pry the trap off the dog's leg with a stick.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective prying I keep my diary locked away from prying eyes.

form.definition: abbreviation for postscript. See you on Saturday, love Jill. PS Don't forget your swimmers!
noun A pseudonym is a false name that someone uses when they don't want to reveal their real name. She entered the competition under a pseudonym.

verb In informal language, if you say that you psych someone into doing something, you mean you get them to do it by using psychological means rather than logical argument. The coach psyched the team into training exceptionally hard by reminding them of their humiliating defeat last year.
psych out In informal language, if you say that you psych someone out in a match or competition, you mean you try to upset them so that you can win.
psych up In informal language, if you say that you psych yourself up to do something, you mean you prepare yourself mentally for it.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLING for this is psyche.

form.definition: noun Your psyche is your mind and emotions.
noun A psychiatrist is a doctor who treats people who are mentally ill.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective psychiatric ...a psychiatric nurse. ...psychiatric problems.noun psychiatry

form.definition: adjective If someone is psychic, they have apparently supernatural mental powers, such as the ability to see the future or to know what other people are thinking. How did you know I was going to say that? You must be psychic! She first became aware of her psychic powers as a teenager.
adjective Psychic also means relating to the mind or emotions. The situation was causing him a good deal of psychic distress.
noun In informal language, a psycho is someone who is mentally disturbed and likely to be violent. Watch out for Billwhen he gets angry he's a bit of a psycho.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective psycho He spent a terrible childhood with a psycho father.

form.definition: noun A psychoanalyst is someone who is trained to help people to understand why they behave or feel the way they do.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb psychoanalyse Don't try to psychoanalyse me!noun psychoanalysis

form.definition: noun If you study psychology, you study the human mind and the reasons for the way people behave.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective psychological noun psychologist

form.definition: abbreviation for please turn over. You can put this at the bottom of a page of writing to show that there is more on the other side.

dictionary.entry: Pty Ltd \times,0\ abbreviation for proprietary limited company. I work for Acme Engineering Pty Ltd.

form.definition: noun Pub is an informal word for a hotel where people go to have alcoholic drinks together.
noun Puberty is the stage in a young person's life when they experience the changes in their body by which they become an adult.
adjective Pubic means relating to the part of the body where the genitals are. ...the pubic bone. ...pubic hair.
adjective If something is public, it belongs to or can be used by all the members of the community. The council is building a new public library.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITE of this is private.

form.definition: adjective If something is public, it is widely known. I don't want the news to become public yet. It's public knowledge that Chris and Marie are getting divorced.
in public If you do something in public, you do it when other people are present. These days he leads a quiet life and rarely appears in public.
the public The public means people in general. The buildings are open to the public on certain days every year.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb publicly He's afraid the scandal would be revealed publicly.

form.definition: noun Public relations is the way a business or organisation presents itself to the public. They need to do something about their public relationsmost people see them as being very old-fashioned.
noun A public school is a school run by the government which provides free education.

dictionary.entry: public servicepV blIk `s@:v@s noun The public service includes every organisation run by the government.
public servantpV blIk `s@:v@nt noun A public servant is anyone who works for a government organisation.

form.definition: noun A publican is someone who runs a pub.
noun The publication of a book occurs when it is printed and made available for sale.
noun In rather formal language, the publication of information means making it available to the public.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb See publish.

form.definition: noun Publicity is the attention given to something in the media. Winning the award created a lot of publicity for the film. He's faced a lot of bad publicity lately over the court case.

verb When a book or newspaper is published, many copies of it are printed for sale to the public. This book was published in 1990it's rather out of date now. Most newspapers refused to publish the gruesome pictures.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun See publication. noun publisher We sell a range of atlases from different publishers.

form.definition: verb If something puckers, it becomes creased. This material is very hard to sewit keeps puckering. When Isabella laughs, the skin around her eyes puckers.
noun A pudding is a sweet food eaten at the end of a meal. There's chocolate ice-cream for pudding.
form.note: ... A MORE FORMAL WORD for this is dessert.

form.definition: noun A puddle is a pool of water on the ground.
noun A puff of something such as smoke is a quick short burst of it. A puff of wind carried the balloon up into a tree.
verb If you puff, you breathe quickly and loudly because you are out of breath. After running up the hill she stood puffing at the summit.
verb To puff something such as smoke is to send it into the air. The old stack at the works is still puffing its smelly fumes.
verb If you puff a cigarette or pipe, or puff on it, you suck smoke into your mouth and then blow it out again. The old sailor sat in the corner puffing his pipe.
noun A puff is also a small pastry cake with cream, fruit or jam in it.

puffed out In informal language, if you say that you are puffed out, you mean you are out of breath because you have exerted yourself physically. Can I sit down for a minute? I'm all puffed out after climbing those stairs.
puff up If something puffs up, it becomes swollen. The tick bite made Anna's eye puff up.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective puffy (puffier, puffiest) My eyes were red and puffy from crying.

form.definition: adjective If someone is pugnacious, they are very aggressive and often get into arguments or fights with other people.

verb If you pull something, you get a firm hold on it and tug on it in order to move it. She pulled her young son away from the water. Pull this lever to operate the machine. The dentist pulled out all his remaining teeth. Can you help me pull off my boots?
verb To pull something is to drag it along. The old horse was slowly pulling the heavy cart. We got stuck behind a car pulling a caravan. The train is pulled by a diesel locomotive.
verb If you pull yourself somewhere, you hang onto something and drag yourself up or away. By holding onto the rope she managed to pull herself from the river onto the bank.
verb If you pull a muscle, you strain it. You injure it so that it hurts and is difficult to use for a while.
pull apart If you pull something apart, you break it up into smaller pieces. Johnny's always pulling his toys apart to see how they work.
pull in If you pull in when you are driving a car, you turn out of the traffic and stop. There's a service station on the leftlet's pull in and get some petrol.
7 pull over If you pull over when you are driving a car, you move to the side of the road.
pull up If you pull up when you are driving a car, you slow down and stop. The police officer signalled to us to pull up.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pull You need to give the door a firm pull to close it.

form.definition: noun Pullover is another word for jumper.
noun The pulp of a fruit is the soft inner part of it.
noun Pulp is any substance which has a soft and sticky consistency, like a very thick paste. Let the newspapers soak for several hours, until they are reduced to a pulp.
noun Pulp is a material made from wood or other fibres which is turned into paper.
noun In informal language, if you say that someone is beaten to a pulp, you mean they are very severely bashed.

noun Your pulse is the regular throbbing you can feel at certain parts of your body, such as your wrist and neck, which shows that your heart is beating and blood is flowing around your body. My pulse was racing after I ran up the hill. His pulse was very weak when they dragged him from the water.
noun A pump is a device that is used to move liquids or gases from one place to another.
noun In particular, a pump is a device for putting air into the tyres of cars or bicycles.[qr

dictionary.entry: My bike has a flat tyrecan I borrow your pump? ... WORD FAMILY verb pump I pumped up heaps of balloons for the party. The water is pumped uphill.

form.definition: noun A pumpkin is a large vegetable with a hard outside. Inside it has orange flesh.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective pumpkin ...pumpkin soup. ...pumpkin pie.

form.definition: noun A pun is a joke involving different words which sound the same, or a word which has more than one meaning.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb pun (puns, punned, punning) 'Where there's a Will there's a way', he said, punning on his own name.

form.definition: verb If someone punches you, they hit you hard with their fist.
noun A punch is a tool that is used for making holes in things.
noun Punch is a mixed drink containing different fruit juices and usually alcohol as well. It is often served from a bowl at parties.

not pull any punches In informal language, if you say that someone doesn't pull any punches, you mean they speak very bluntly and critically. They go straight to the point. I didn't pull any punchesI told him just what I thought of his behaviour.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun punch I felt a punch in my ribs.verb punch She punched an extra hole in the belt.

form.definition: adjective If someone is punctual, they are always on time for meetings and appointments. Bruce is usually very punctualhe should be here any minute.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun punctuality Punctuality is important in Australian business culture.

form.definition: noun Punctuation is the signs such as commas, full stops and question marks that are added to written language to help make the meaning clear.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb punctuate How would you punctuate this sentence?

form.definition: noun A puncture in something such as a tyre or balloon is a hole in it made by a sharp object. The air inside escapes through the puncture and the balloon or tyre deflates. Nick rode his bicycle over a nail and got a puncture in his front tyre.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb puncture The bullet punctured his lung.

form.definition: verb If you punish someone, you make them suffer in some way because they have done something wrong. Tom's been sent to his room to punish him for speaking so rudely. The offence may be punished by a fine of up to $1000.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun punishment

form.definition: verb In informal language, if you say that you punt on something, you mean you bet on it. I never normally gamble, but I do punt on the Melbourne cup each year. We're all punting on you winning the freestyle.
noun A punt is a long boat with a flat bottom and square ends. You move it along in shallow water by pushing a pole against the bottom of the river or lake.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun punt I took a punt on Lucky Lady and it won.verb punt We went punting down the river.

form.definition: adjective If a person or animal is puny, they are very small and weak. The last pup to be born was very puny and died during the night. What a puny excusedo you expect me to believe you?
noun A pup is a young dog which is not fully grown.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is puppy.

form.definition: noun A pupil is a student at a school.
noun The pupil in your eye is the small round black hole in the centre of the coloured iris.

noun A puppet is a doll or figure which can be made to move as if it were alive. Some puppets have strings attached to their arms and legs, which move when the strings are pulled. Other puppets are made so that you can move them by putting your hand inside.
noun If you call someone a puppet, you mean that their actions are completely controlled by someone else. The new manager hasn't shown any initiativehe's just a puppet of head office.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun puppeteer

form.definition: verb In formal language, if you say that someone purchases something, you mean they buy it. Mr and Mrs Raven agree to purchase the house, subject to a pest inspection.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun purchase The boat turned out to be a wise purchase.noun purchaser I showed the car to a prospective purchaser.

form.definition: adjective If something is pure, it is not mixed with anything else. This blouse is pure silk. Pure gold is too soft to be used in jewellery.
adjective If something is pure, it is clean and healthy. I prefer mineral water to tap water because it tastes so pure.
adjective If something such as a colour or sound is pure, it is clear and bright. The boy soprano's voice is so pure as it soars above the chorus. The room is decorated in pure reds and blues.
adjective Pure can also mean 'nothing other than'. He succeeded by pure hard work. It was pure chance that I happened to meet her.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adverb purely verb purify (purifies, purified, purifying) noun purity

form.definition: noun A puree is a food that has been broken down into very small particles so that it forms a smooth soft paste. The crepes are filled with a puree of spinach and walnut.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY verb puree

form.definition: verb If you purge something of unwanted things, you get rid of them. After the crisis, the leaders purged the party of all its pro-democratic members. Moving was a good incentive to purge my wardrobe of a lot of old jumpers.
verb If you purge something from somewhere, you get rid of it. Jinx resolved to purge unkind thoughts from her mind. You should periodically purge files you no longer need from your hard disc.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun purge She was expelled from the party in a political purge.

form.definition: noun Purple is a dark reddish blue.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective purple

form.definition: noun The purpose of something is the reason for which it exists or is done. What's the purpose of this handle? The purpose of this test is to check the function of your kidneys.

noun Your purpose in doing something is your aim or intention. I knocked on the door and explained my purpose. I arrived early with the purpose of speaking to Belinda alone. It's not very elegant, but it's good enough for my purposes.
noun Purpose is also the determination you feel to do something you think is important. Once I'd taken the decision I felt a renewed sense of purpose. He strode along the street with purpose.
on purpose If you do something on purpose, you do it intentionally. You're just trying to annoy me on purpose. I asked the question on purpose to see what her reaction would be.
verb When a cat purrs, it makes a low vibrating noise in its throat. The cat purred with pleasure as Diana stroked it.
verb If something such as a engine purrs, it makes a low humming noise. The big car purred up the hills without strain.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun purr

form.definition: noun A purse is a small bag which people, especially women, keep their money in. Often women keep their purse in a larger bag called a handbag.

verb If you purse your lips, you draw them up into a rounded shape. Often people do this because they disapprove of something, or they are trying to decide whether they like something, or they have eaten something bitter.
verb If someone pursues something, they follow it in order to catch it. The police pursued the stolen vehicle until it ran out of petrol.
verb If you pursue something such as an aim or a dream, you try to achieve it.

verb In rather formal language, if you pursue a course of action, you keep on with it. This initial success encouraged me to pursue my investigations. Unfortunately we haven't got time to pursue this fascinating topic.

verb In rather formal language, if you pursue a certain activity, you carry it out. You do it. He has pursued a successful career in the legal profession. Our company pursues an equal opportunities policy.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun pursuer I dived into an alley to evade my pursuer.noun pursuit He drove off at speed, with the police car in pursuit.

form.definition: noun Pus is a thick yellowish liquid which forms in an infected wound.
verb If you push something, you use force on it to make it move forward. Jenny pushed her brother into the swimming pool. I got into the lift and pushed the button for the fifth floor.
verb If you push something, you make it move along in front of you as you go forward. Here's a photo of me pushing the lawnmower. I had to get off and push the bike up the hill.
verb If you push somewhere, you get there by pressing things or people out of the way so that you can squeeze through. She somehow managed to push to the front of the crowd.
verb In informal language, if you say that someone pushes you to do something, you mean they urge you strongly to do it. My father kept pushing me to accept the job.

In informal language, if you say that someone pushes you into doing something, you mean they persuade you to do it even though you don't really want to. I'd never have entered the competition if my friends hadn't pushed me into it. Never let yourself be pushed into drinking more than you're comfortable with.

verb In informal language, if you say that someone pushes a product or an idea, you mean they try hard to get people interested in it. They're really pushing this new shampoothere are posters everywhere. Gerry's been pushing this idea of a cycling holiday, but I'm not very keen.

at a push In informal language, if you say that you could do something at a push, you mean it would be difficult and you would only do it if it were absolutely necessary. I could lend you $200 at a pushbut I'd have to scrape it together.

push off In informal language, if you say that you're going to push off, you mean you're about to leave. This phrase is also sometimes used rudely, to tell someone to go away. It's after tenI'd better push off now. Push off, Misha, you've caused enough trouble already.
push on In informal language, if you say that you'll push on with something, you mean you'll keep on doing it or you'll start to do it again. I'd better push on with my work now the rain's stopped.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY noun push Give the door a pushit's rather stiff.

form.definition: adjective In informal language, if you say that you're pushed for something, you mean you don't have enough of it. Sorry, I can't stop nowI'm a bit pushed for time. We're really pushed for cash now that Marcia's only working part-time.

hard pushed In informal language, if you say that you're hard pushed to do something, you mean that you find it very difficult. We'll be hard pushed to finish by six. I'm hard pushed to understand how he could be so unfriendly after our good times together.
noun Pusher is another word for a stroller.
noun In informal language, a pushover is something that you find very easy. For someone with your skills, the exam should be a pushover.
noun In informal language, if you say that someone is a pushover, you mean they are very easy to persuade or deceive. Don't worry about Dad giving us the moneyhe's a real pushover!

noun A push-up is an exercise that you can do to strengthen your muscles. You lie face down on the floor and use your arms to raise the top part of your body. He did twenty push-ups every morning before his shower.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORD for this is press-up.

form.definition: verb If you put something somewhere, you move it from somewhere else and leave it in that place. Could you put the plates and glasses on the table? I put my hand on hers. We've put up new curtains in the lounge room. I only put my bag down for a moment and someone stole it.

verb If you put something such as effort or money into something, you devote it to that cause. Steve has put a lot of time into this assignment. Her father agreed to put $10 000 into the business. You only get as much out of a relationship as you're prepared to put in.

verb If you put something that you say or write in a particular way, that is how you express it. Let's put it this way: I won't be upset if she decides to leave. You need to put your main point more forcefully.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you put something to someone, you mean you suggest it to them. I'll put your proposal to the boss, but I don't think she'll go along with it. I put it to you that your statement is a complete fabrication.
put away If you put something away, you place it where it is usually stored. Put your toys away now, please. I emptied the dishwasher and put away the dishes.
put down (a) If someone puts you down, they cause you to seem inferior or stupid. I hate it when Dad puts me down in front of my friends.
(b) When a vet puts down an animal, they kill it humanely. Unfortunately we had to have our old dog put down last week.

put off (a) If you put something off, you delay doing it. You postpone it until later. I meant to go and visit her, but somehow I kept putting it off. We decided to put off our expedition in view of the rain.

(b) If something puts you off, it discourages you or makes you less keen about doing something. Don't let her manner put you offshe's very nice really. I wanted to learn Japanese, but I got put off when I found out how hard it was. The dirt in the kitchen really put me off.
put on If you put on your clothes, you get dressed in them. He took off his shorts and put on a pair of trousers.
put up with If you put up with something, you tolerate it even though you don't like it. I've been putting up with a toothache rather than go to the dentist.
noun Putty is a soft paste which you use around windows to hold the glass in place, and to fill cracks and holes in walls. When it dries, it becomes hard and firm.
noun A puzzle is a something mysterious. You don't understand it. It's a puzzle how the vase got broken while we were all out. Mathematics has always been a hopeless puzzle to me.

noun A puzzle is also a game or competition which takes time and effort to work out. I bought a book of puzzles for the journey. The point of this puzzle is to separate the two metal rings. ...a crossword puzzle. ...a jigsaw puzzle.
verb If something puzzles you, you don't undertand it. You feel confused or curious about it. Mary puzzles me with her mood changes. What puzzles me is where he got the money from.

puzzle over If you puzzle over something, you spend a lot of time trying to understand it or work it out. I'm still puzzling over her sudden disappearance. Poor Jenny sat upstairs puzzling over her homework.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILY adjective puzzled She looked at me with a puzzled expression.adjective puzzling Scientists are investigating this puzzling phenomenon.

form.definition: noun Pyjamas are a set of loose pants and shirt for wearing in bed.
noun A pylon is a tall steel tower that supports electricity cables.
noun A pylon is also a tall support at the end of a bridge.
noun A pyramid is a solid shape which has a square base and four triangular sides which slope up to a central peak.
noun The pyramids of ancient Egypt are huge stone monuments built to house the bodies of dead rulers.
noun A python is a large snake. It is not venomous, but it winds around its prey and squeezes it tightly until it dies.[fa[xp
